We spent most of the day, on our porch, at four O.clock, a Three Seated Carriage drove up, and Mr & Mrs Harvey, Sr, with Mr & Mrs George and two daughters, Elbert and Paul Harvey. all came to call, Paul was driving, Frances treated all to Cake and ginger Ale, and Burch beer. they seemed very happy. they returned home at five, Mrs Harvey, and family to Kenwood, and Mr George Hearvey,s family to their home at Evanston, Shreve, Frances, and Ada took tea to night with Mr & Mrs Loyd, at Kenilworth.

Ned & Shreve bad colds.  Monday July 15, 1901  It is cloudy today, a little warmer than yesterday, all better of their colds but baby Shreve, he coughs a great deal, a real Bronchitis cough. Ada gone in town to make a few calls, Miss Mollen still sewing for Ada. Ada returned at five, she called on the Botsfords, Mrs Fish & Mrs Robert Harvey, then called on the Drews, she took Luncheon by invitation with Mrs Walsh, Ellen Wash, Richard Walsh, and Ida Drew all took luncheon with Mrs John Walsh, Mrs Walsh gave Ada a nice large silk Bag for her sewing, Mrs Caroline Fisher sent Ada a handsome skirt of Lace.  My son Sheridan returned from Marquette to day, had a lovely visit and was delightfully entertained by the Breitings and the Haufmans.

Nana and Mrs A.C. Badger have bad colds.  Tuesday, July 16, 1901  Today has been very warm, all of us stayed at home, Ada this afternoon went to the Lake and Saw Many in bathing good bathrooms this is on the Lake Shore front of Kenilworth, all of us well but baby Shreve, he has Bronchitis with high fever, so Francis sent for Dr Stolp of this place, her Dr Snyder gone down the St Lawrence, baby is quite sick, I forgot that Edwin Badger has the same bad cold, all the family at home today. My son Shreve so uneasy about baby Shreve, he has several times telephoned to inquire how he is, there is so much of the Mother in Shreve,s heart that he suffers when his children are ill,

Carleton Badger ill with Typhoid fever.  Wednesday, July 17, 1901  This has been a good day but very warm, after breakfast, Miss Ada Badger Mrs Shreve Badger Nana & Ned also Mrs Reardin all went to our Beach to take a swim, they enjoyed it, and say the Beach is a fine One, all at home this afternoon that is why, so many little things have been finished and unclear  At ten O,clock We had a very severe electrical Storm, which lasted over an hour, at twelve O clock it was all over, I thought our house was struck once or twice the stars came out at midnight and we all slept well. Dr. Stolp called to see baby, says he is better, and left him, to keep his bed until, to morrow.  Ida May Henry, is at Battle creek having gone through an operation which will keep her in bed six weeks, her sister are with her None of them are strong

Baby Shreve & Ned have bad colds.  Thursday, July 18, 1901  This is a beautiful day. all of us well. The severe storm of last night has made everything look so beautiful. Baby Shreve up and dresses, and feels much better. Frances gone down town to make some purchases, Ada Badger has headache. I wrote to Mrs Hardy at Louisville Office of the evening Post. Mr Shreve Badger brought home to night a box with two beautiful brown & white Collie Pups. Ed the coloured man, brought them to the North Western deport, Mr Harvey sent them to Mr Shreve Badger. One for him, and one for Mr Turner, who owns The Father, named Sandy, The Mother Mr Harvey owns, named Maidee. Many of Ada,s handsome clothes has come home from Mrs Cone. They are beautiful, a telegram came to night to Ada saying, Mr Swearingen would be here in the morning. All well here but Nana and Mr A.C. Badger who has Bronchitis and high fever.

Mr Swearingen leaves to night for Chicago X  Friday, July 19, 1901  Today has been warm and sunny after breakfast, Ada and I went to Chicago to purchase shoes, ribbons and lace, Met David Badger on the street, he just arrived from Louisville, and going to Hoshkonong to meet his Father Mother, Two Sisters and Miss Jeane Bouk, Mr Edward Henry will join them to morrow he has gone to Columbus to see a doctor about his arm he broke playing Basket ball. We met Ida Drew, and Miss Bertha Chapman, we went in to get soda water, and these two girls came in. Ida Drew said she was to be married in September, she was delighted  a high fever came on me at eleven O. clock and did not leave me until nine O. clock to night it is Bronchitis we went to Dr Zeislers, his wife has appendicitis and is ill, so he cant go away. To night Mr Shreve Badger Mrs Shreve Badger and Miss Ada Badger all gone to Chicago to the Theatre. Carleton Badger ill at Riverside with Typhoid fever.

Mr Swearingen arrived this morning. Mr & Mrs A.C. Badger go to T.W. Harveys for a visit X  X X Saturday, July 20, 1901  This is a beautiful day. not so warm all better of colds, my cough still very troublesome. Mr Swearingen arrived at nine O, clock. this afternoon Mr Badger and I go X to Mrs T.W. Harveys to Stay a few days. Ada Badger and Mr Swearingen go to Mrs Harveys on Sunday. Ada Badger dont feel well. Mrs Philip Stewart is expected in Chicago on Monday. Miss Mollen is still sewing here for Frances. all work is nearly finished Mr Badger came out to Kenilworth to get me. my satchel was ready, and we started on the five O clock train. Frances ordered the little carriage for us to go to the station we took the Illinois train, to 58th street there we met Elbert with a light Carrette, and we rode to the house down it saved me many steps Mr Harvey and Belle were on the Porch to welcome us with outstretched arms, we enjoy their beautiful grounds and handsome house.

Shreve brought on the 18, two beautiful Collies very young-  Sunday, July 21, 1901  It is late and I must hasten to a unclear all are well here but me with a bad cough, Mrs Harvey is trying to cure me, to day is the hottest day we have, in the shade it is over one hundred. Gertrude and Sheridan came to see us this afternoon, from Western Springs near Riverside, we ought to appreciate their visit Then later Jeane Harvey came  with her three children, to make her call, her husband Charles Harvey is on buisness in California, so our day passed off finely topping off with ginger Ale and cake.

William Wirt had measeles last week at Mrs George Henry,  Monday, July 22 1901   Today is beautiful and cool, of change of blank degrees from yesterday all well but my cough which is very bad  Ada Henry came with William Wirt and Camille, they have just returned from Mrs George Henry,s in the country, Mr R L Henry had two new flowing wells Beaumont Texas. Mr Harvey has had some success with his Oil. William Wirt is just over the measeles, he had them at Mrs George Henry,s. all are well now. After Luncheon, Mrs Henry took me to Marshal Feilds to meet Mr Badger to go out to Kenilworth, but we found out, we had friends at Shreve,s for a day or two, so returned to Mrs T.W. Harveys,s for a few days Mrs Philip Stewart is the One visiting there and Frances, after we returned to my daughters Mrs Harvey,s we found them at supper, they were delighted at our coming back to their delightful house, which is a beautiful collinaded block of ground , with house in the center built by Q. Y . Scammons, she dies this spring, he died years ago.

Mrs Philip Stewart making Shreve a little visit  Tuesday, July 23, 1901  Elbert and Mrs Harvey gone to hear Prof Moutton. This has been a clear sunny day with a good Breeze, so we have not at all suffered. We stayed at home all Morning Sewing and reading, after Luncheon, Elbert Harvey and his mother went to the University to hear a lecture of Prof, Morton, all well here but me, my cough still holds Belle late today altered the neck of my black poplin, I had hoped to see all at Kenilworth to night but Mrs Stewart is there visiting her cousin Mrs Shreve Badger Mrs Harveys place looks beautiful and the fountain in his yard , opposite the front door is filled with water and the birds come and drink it is a lovely sight Elbert gone walking , Mr Harvey is reading a work Mrs Harvey had a letter from Paul, at Oil City, expects to visit Spring Luke, he says life at Mrs Bland Ballards house, is what he calls living, I agree with him, I call it a real ideal home, of beauty & good management.

Wednesday, July 24, 1901  There is a good breeze, but it is cloudy and looks like rain, all are in health here at Mr Harveys, I am complaining still of my severe cough. We are thinking of going to Kenilworth to night, Mrs Philip Stewart is going to day to her Brother,s home at Lake Geneva, for a visit, she lives at Denver. Mr Harvey and Mr Badger gone to their buisiness down town, Elbert gone to his summer lectures. It now threatens a storm, which perhaps will change our plans. I think the Houstons to day will leave Spring Lake, and go to old Sweet Springs, Virginia It is nearing Ada,s wedding, and we have much to do. Poor Ada is just beginning to realize that she is to leave us, and go to another City to live, and she is quite broken up, she wants me to come and live with her in Louisville, she has been with me ever since her birth, her beautiful saintly Mother died at her Birth, so she never knew but me, her twin sister Belle, only lived until she was 11 months old.

Thursday, July 25, 1901  Again a beautiful day but warm My cough is still very exhausting, we all stayed at home, Mrs Harvey is trying to fix for herself a beautiful black thread lace dress over white silk, so we have looked at Vogue. and Belle thinks she can make it a beauty. She worked all of three days, but we got Miss Mollen to come, and help, and they finished it in good style, and Belle was greatly releived, she had given me so much of her time, Nursing me, and putting on hot poltices, that she could not have time for herself, but she got to the wedding on time at Kenilworth Illinois. Mr T.W. Harvey Mrs Harvey and Elbert came to Adas wedding on good time. Recipe for wrinkle remover. Human kindness, one part; sweet thoughts two parts, mix with mental sunshine, and apply all the time, Rev Dr Willits said he never worried. That you must not worry about things that cant be helped, and never worry over things that can be helped, but get up and go and do them.

Dr Lundgren to see Mrs Badger  (Ada Badger comes to day. Mrs Badger sick in Bed at Mrs Harveys  Friday, July 26, 1901  It is again very warm, all well, but me at three O clock Mrs Harvey & I got ready and ordered the Carette to go to Kenilworth when Belle thought she would like the opinion of Dr Lundgren about my cough. so she telephoned for him, he came at once, examined my lunngs, and said I must not go home, as both my lungs were affected and I had Bronchial Pneumonia on me. and I must not go home, or we would have a funeral, instead of a Wedding of course I insisted, but the Dr begged me to stay, and I yeilded, as I knew he was right, so to bed I went, like a cross child and stayed five days. With large hot poultices of Flax seed meal. put on my chest and pourous plaster on my back. and many remedies, to take of pills, but it cured me very quickly, but my poor daughter Belle worked over me, day and night, at three O. clock in the morning she would creep in with hot poultice and hot water to drink, three times a day I had egg punches, and soft boiled eggs, as the doctor said that was the best thing for me Belle is certainly the best trained Nurse I ever saw, she bathed and Massaged me, and was untiring-and self sacrificing-

Mr. Swearingen arrived at 7 -  Saturday, July 27, 1901  A beautiful day, all well but me. the very hot poultices are to be kept up three days all over my chest, as a porous plaster on my back over my lungs. and I am to stay in bed. this is sad news for me as I wanted to hurry back to my home, to help my daughter Ada with her Wedding, Mr Swearingen arrived here at Mr Harvey,s at seven O.clock, from Louisville, to visit Miss Ada Badger, who he is to marry the 7th of Aug, all down stairs seem to be having such a good time, I can hear their laughter, Elbert is so good, he comes up and waits on me, brings me hot water to drink, and milk punch, he is a dear young man, and such a help to his Mother, he has kept himself very busy this summer, at the University in Chicago, he has taken the Summer course of study, there was a very large number of Students, and the lectures given by the Professors, have drawn large crowds, and the Summer, class was a very large one, Llewellyn Henry is also a summer student. and a Champion runner. he has always been a fine scholar.

Mr. Lundgren for Mrs Badger, Mr Swearingen returned to Kentucky.  Sunday, July 28, 1901  This morning threatened rain, and we had during the day several Severe electrical storms, all stayed at home, even Mr. A.C. Badger, could not make his usual family calls, it poured rain, Mr Harvey left to night for Milwaukee, and Mr. Swearingen left the house at eight for Louisville Kentucky, he came down to see Miss Ada Badger he is a widower with two children, Lulla & George we are all very fond of him, he seems so kind, and comes from a lovely family his Father has always been a very fine buisness man, but

Ada returned to Kenilworth, Dr Willets, Verses  Monday, July 29, 1901  Today is fair, I am still in bed, but better, after breakfast Ada Badger said Good Bye and Started to Kenilworth. Mr Badger returned at Six, feeling quite tired, he had gone to Kenilworth to get clean clothes for us both, as we are visiting longer than we expected, Ada only stayed here a few days. Belle,s family keeps well. Paul is at Spring Lake. Elbert is at home. he and I will go to Spring Lake together, Mr Badger will come on Later,  X  X  Rev Dr WIllets who preaches at Spring Lake and gives lectures as around the Country D met us on the train, and told us of this circumstance, and we asked him to write it down, he said twenty years ago, A young man asked me for my autograph, I took his book, and wrote this impromptu verse. 
If in life,s contest you would win, 
Be not afraid of work.
From duty never shrink
And be ashamed of naught but Sin (A.A. Willits, A few days ago, I met him again, and he told me, about the Verse, I said, he had run his life on those lines, & was now the Pastor of a prominent Christian Church.)

dressed Mrs Badger  Tuesday, July 30, 1901  Today is beautiful and sunny, but very warm all here well but me, I am much better of my Bronchial Pneumonia, got up and dressed and went for awhile into Mrs Harvey,s room, then laid down again, Mrs Harvey and Dr Lundgren with their heroic treatment, have broken up the severe attack, they have used such good remedies, that my severe cough of long Standing had to yeild,   After Luncheon Mrs Harvey had some errands at Marshall Fields, so she went and left her son Elbert with me, and Annie, and Ed, her coloured servants to wait on me, they are true, faithful old family servants, good as gold. So I was well cared for. And as to Elbert Harvey, my Grandson, there are not words enough to express what a jewel he is, manly, tender courteous, self sacrificing, always willing to accommodate himself to your wishes and yet a man of force, and ability, and a great student but his sweet disposition, and christian character, with a level head, he is just like his Mother, with many forceful traits like his Father. I think him perfect.

Russell Houstons baby dead July 27  Wednesday, July 31, 1901  Mrs Judge Bland Ballard dies Aug 2nd  This is a beautiful day sunny & fresh breeze. Mr Harvey did not feel good to day, as he has been travelling for some days, all the rest well. Past night Mr Badger dined with Mrs Henry Mr Henry gone to Beaumont Texas to his oil wells, after dinner Mr Henry ordered her Carriage and took Mr Badger a drive through the Park, LLewellyn was with them Then they brought Mr Badger home. Today Mrs Harvey is having her large Rugs put all over the house, so they look very fine, blank blank died August 2nd  Mrs Sarah McDowell Ballard) daughter of late Dr William A, McDowell, her husband Judge Bland Ballard, presided over the United States District Court of Kentucky, he has been dead 22 years, they have five children, Mr Charles Davidson of Cincinnati, Mr Bland, and Austin, Ballard & Miss Fanny & Susie Ballard.

Mrs Badger went down to luncheon, first time since sick,  X  Thursday, August 1, 1901  Mr Badger came home sick at noon.  Today is perfect, neither too warm or cold, a lovely breeze, I arose at nine after my bath, and rubbing of Vasalene my daughter Belle is so anxious to have me well, before I return home to Kenilworth, so she is doing all we possibly could do, and giving me all the tonic, and Egg punches, and five meals a day, all dainty and nourishing, but not too much at a time, so I am fine, after my daughters Belle & good care I went down to Luncheon, first time for eleven days, felt pretty well, food taste,s better, Receive a nice letter from Aunt Carrie Stanwood at Philadelphia, all her family at home but Charley and May. Mrs. T.B. Blackstone, sent me a lovely letter of thanks for the Golden Wedding Book I sent her, the letter went wrong that is why I was so long in getting it. Ada has received many gift, very costly from her friends, this is a busy week, I being away from home,

Mrs Judge Bland Ballard died to day. Judge Bland Ballard died 20 years ago  Friday, August 2, 1901  This is a beautiful day, sunny and strong breeze. We are all well pleased with our improvements, Mr Badger feeling very relieved of his pain in his stomach and my cough so much better. We both went down to Luncheon. Our breakfast was taken in bed, Elbert getting ready to go to Spring Lake, right after the wedding, A letter from Paul says he is so happy he would like to stay a few days more, A postal from Mrs Shreve at Spring Lake just learned of My illness, but I wrote her that I was now all right, through my daughter Belle,s devoted cure, It has clouded up and looks like a storm. We expect to say good Bye to my daughter Belle, and family to morrow, and return to Kenilworth, we would love to stay longer, we have had such a sweet time alltogether, and lonely Elbert to read to us, and bring us good things, The storm has passed us, and now the sun is shining again, Mr Harvey has brought up some beautiful China Plates Bouillion Cups & saucers & Silver candlesticks for Mrs Harvey to select for Ada Badger,s wedding gift

I go back to Kenilworth after Luncheon & Mr Badger.  X    Saturday, August 3, 1901  Mr Swearingen arrived this morning  It looks very cloudy and threatens rain, but not very warm, all are well here but me but I am so improved that I almost feel well, I have a little cough left and feel weak, at eleven Mrs Henry came to Mrs Harvey,s to Luncheon, our party was Mrs Harvey, Mrs Henry, Mrs A.C. Badger, and Elbert and Mr A.C. Badger, who has been here sick with his old stomach trouble which he has had come and go many years, he has the pain so severe he can scarce walk a step, it lasts for three or four days, and then he grows better. it was planned for Mrs Harvey to go to Kenilworth with us, but as Mr Badger was with me, Belle remained home. and at three O, clock Mr Badger, Mrs Henry, Elbert and myself, all went to the North Western Depot, said good Bye to Mrs Henry and Elbert, and took train for Kenilworth, arrived on time, and felt pretty well not as weak, as I was afraid I would. all at our house delighted to see me, soon we had dinner, and I went to my room, sat and talked until late, but I did not feel worse. Mr Swearingen arrived in the morning, from Louisville to stay until after the Wedding, he looks well and happy. he is such a nice man.

Mrs Bland Ballard so died suddenly Aug 2nd  Sunday, August 4, 1901  This is a beautiful day, all are well here now. We had breakfast at nine and I came down I am feeling better, so is Mr Badger. weather cool. Mr Swearingen brought the news, yesterday that old Mrs Bland Ballard had suddenly died of heart desease in Louisville (on Friday) and Mr & Mrs Bland Ballard Jr. were on their way to the funeral in Louisville, they left Mrs Shreve their mother in Spring Lake New Jersey, A telegram came from Mrs & Miss Gertrude Clark, saying they were delayed, on the train from San Diego California, they will arrive Monday- Mrs & Miss Clark have come for Ada,s wedding, Miss Clark will stay at our house at Kenilworth. Mrs Clark will stay at Beach Hotel, two days after the wedding Mrs & Miss Clark will visit relatives in Canada. Ada,s Trousseau was very handsome, she was nicely fit out, her tan travelling suit was very pretty, and becoming, so was her light grey suit. She had a great many summer clothes, and two pretty golf suits, and many pretty shirt waists, Many things were made at home by our dressmaker and many made out of the house.

Miss Mollen sews to day for Belle Harvey, to finish her her gown for wedding. Monday, August 5, 1901  Miss Gertrude Clark arrived to night at eight  X  This is another beautiful day, all well. I am well again, Mrs Harveys good Nursing and Dr Lundgren has brought me right up. Thats to a good Providence who ordered all things. Mrs Henry says, she wants to cure me now to cure me of fear, and so she wont let me touch my medicine, so you see what good hands we are in. Mr Swearingen here to spend the day, he has Vacation to spend with his sweetheart. he will spend his days at Mrs Harveys, and nights at Hotel  Miss Mollen, Ada,s dressmaker will go Monday to help Mrs Harvey with her dress, for the Wedding, as my sickness put her back, then Miss Mollen will come here, and dress the bride, Frances is still moving furniture for wedding with two men, Carrie & Ellen doing cleaning, and will wait on Ladies. Mr Swearinger and Ada have gone to Chicago. I wrote notes of condolence to Misses Ballard at Louisville, also to Mr & Mrs Austin Ballard same place, and cards to Mr & Mrs Bland Ballard of Spring Lake N.J. wrote to Mrs Shreve, All the family to night were dancing the Cake walk, when little Shreve ran past them and fell, and tripped the others and one or two fell on Shreve, and almost knocked the breath out of him, he was ill.

day before Wedding.       Mr Comstock dead.  Tuesday, August 6, 1901  This has been a busy day. all of us well baby Shreve recovered from his fall. Ada gone to Eranston to call on her Motherinlaw to be Mrs G.W. Swearingen she arrived this morning from Louisville with her three Grandchildren and coloured Nurse. at One O, clock all this party with Mr Swearingen and Ada drove to Kenilworth to take Luncheon with Mrs Shreve Badger. soon my daughter Mrs T.W. Harvey and A.C. Badger came to Luncheon. We had a lovely time, and all enjoyed the day. Poor little Shreve had another tumble on the back of his head. Our party returned to their Hotel at six.  they could not stay to dinner Mrs Swearingen is a handsome woman. Miss Clark went into town to see her Mother. returned at five, O clock. Presents coming in from many. Mrs Harvey went home at six at seven Mrs U.F. Badger, Belle & Adele came from Hoshkonong and stay with us until after the wedding. Mr Cornstock of Green Bay died to day, he is Mr Shreve Badgers friend.

This is Ada C. Badgers Wedding day.  Wednesday, August 7, 1901  This is a glorious day sunny and cool, all well we rose at six, as there was much to do. Frances and Miss Gertrude Clark did a great in arranging the flowers, and the whole house looked beautiful and the Marriage Belle was suspended in the Hall. at eleven O clock all was finished, and we all went to dressing ourselves to be prompt. Soon Mrs R L Henry Nurse & five children came and we gave them a room to dress in, then Mrs Harvey & Mr Harvey, Elbert & Belle Mason, cam, then Mr Swearingen, his mother & three grandchildren & Nurse came, and had rooms, then Rev Stires & Wife and Sister came. When the band of Johnny Hand,s which was stationed at the head of the stairs played the Wedding march Mr. A.C. Badger walked down the stairs daughter on his arm and Mr Badger and relatives followed, after the ceremony they had the kissing and congratulations, and then all repaired to the dining room, where There was a bountiful feast, the table looked lovely, with a large center of white lilies, soon the Bride went up and put on their Travelling clothes, dress of tan cloth. The bride looked handsome, so did Mr Swearingen. They started off, amid rice, and shoes. Ada made a beautiful bride, was so smiling and gracious. and happy.

day after Wedding, Mrs U, F. Badger & children gone to Hoshkonong at four Ocloc
This has been a glorious day, all well at eleven, Mrs U. F. Badger went into the City to meet Mrs. Bouk, at four Mrs. Shreve Badger, MIss Gertrude Clark & two of Mrs U, F, Badgers daughters went to Fields to meet their Mother. Mrs. Harvey & Belle Mason went to Fields to see all so did Mrs several others, also Mr A C Badger Miss Clark met her Mother at the Beach Hotel, it is a beautiful resort Harry Stanwood, Mr A.C. Badgers Cousin. is expected here soon, from Louisana where he has been visiting his Aunts, Mrs Dr Buck, and Mrs Dr Duval.

Mrs Badger and Elbert Harvey left for Spring Lake To day.  Friday, August 9, 1901  If God is willing, we soon will start on our journey, we rose at six, had breakfast at Kenilworth, and went in the Carriage to Chicago, took another Carriage and rode to another depot, there we waited for our party, soon Mr & Mrs Harvey and Belle Mason and Elbert came. Then Mr Badger and Sheridan, then Shreve, Frances & baby Shreve, soon our Train was ready and we said "good Bye" and started on the nickel plated road to New York, we had nice lower berths I had one, and Elbert had another, Mrs Harvey gave us three boxes of lunch, one of fruit Plums, peaches, Pears & bananas then sandwiches of Veal, Beef & chicken hard boiled eggs, Olives, coffee buns, and Angels food, Ice water and coffee. We had such and abundance, that it did us for two days, our time passed pleasantly and we reached New York Saturday at four O. clock. we took Cars to Ferry Boat got on boat and had a nice Trip, we landed, and took cars for Spring Lake, arrived there at seven, took stage to the house, and was received with open arms by the whole crowd Dr & Mrs Thruston Ballard, son, and Nurse, are here too, for a few weeks.

Mrs A.C. Badger Elbert Harvey arrived at five at Spring Lake N.J.  Saturday, August 10, 1901  Sun Shines bright, we are well, and rose at seven, had a very good sleep in my berth, Elbert had a berth near me. we travelled along all night without any disturbances, took our breakfast at eight, enjoyed the delicious boxes of fruit Mrs Harvey gave us, all day we read, and enjoyed the scenery and at four O. clock, we reached New York, took the Cars to the Ferry. got on the boat, and enjoyed the water and as soon as we reached the opposite side, we got off the boat, took cars for Spring Lake and reached the Cottage at seven O. clock, all rushed to us with open arms, and were delighted to see us, we had a delightful dinner. Mr & Mrs Thruston Ballard with their four year old son, and Nurse, have been here at Mrs Bland Ballard for ten days, and Paul Harvey will be here for several days The little boys name was Rogers. Ballard who live in Louisville, their 18 year old daughter came to Mrs Ballards often to lunch, but was staying with her friend. Miss Thomas. Their Cottage I think was near Monmouth. Mrs Thruston Ballard is a very handsome and sylish woman, and goes a great deal in Society

Rogers Ballard had his four year birthday at Bland Ballards, Spring Lake New Jersey.  Sunday, August 11, 1901  A beautiful day, all well, Mr & Mrs Bland Ballard went to church with his boys Bland. Jr. and Little Shreve, after dinner we had a party come to dine with the Ballards, Miss Thomas & Miss Mary Ballard, they dined with us. Mrs Ballard had a small table the the dining room with a birthday cake on it, with four candles, and Ice Cream, and several toys for the Rogers Ballard boy, he four year old, he was delighted we had a fine dinner and all enjoyed the children, they were Bland Jr. Little Shreve Belle Sheridan and little Rogers, all seated at their small table, he is their only son. and they worship him, they lost a son, I think two years ago, That nearly killed Mr Ballard, so of course this attractive little fellow has won all hearts, they have only this boy, and Mary who is eighteen years old, they live on the Highlands in Louisville and have built a very handsome house with large grounds. and they entertain very much, give many house parties that are delightful. both of them are very gay. and love company, and they have everything New, and fine, so they dont have much care.

Monday, August 12, 1901  When we woke it was pouring rain, and continued so until this afternoon, Mrs Austin Ballard went this afternoon to see her Brother Mr Creedo Harris & wife who have a Cottage near to Spring Lake. Mr Ballard and his daughter Mary, Rogers & Nurse, all went to see Mrs Thomas, our party were going to drive out to the Munsey Road and take lunch but rain prevented. Received letter from Mattie Badger and little Adele from Hoshkonong They all well, Miss Bouk & Louise Bouk are with Mattie, we think that David Badger being so much in love her, that they will make a match of it, she is a very interesting young lady of fine education and good musician, her Parents are lovely people. They have been so kind to Mattie and family they really fell in love with each other whe they first met. They are a very handsome family, and so kind and considerate they have two daughters and one son, he married well, and is a good buisiness man, his wife is rich, they have one baby.

Paul Harvey started for Chicago, but returned to night as his ticket was not right.   Tuesday, August 13, 1901  It is cloudy this morning, Mrs Bland Ballard rose early this morning and went to the depot with Paul Harvey, he has gone home to Chicago, he has been absent one month Elbert will remain until Sept. we are all well, there is a Trip on hand this morning for our party to the Rumsey Road to spend the day. The party will be Mr & Mrs Bland Ballard, Mr & Mrs Thruston Ballard and Elbert, and their daughter, Mary Ballard. as it looks like rain the Trip is given up. and Mrs Thruston Ballard will go to Mrs Donevans to Luncheon. after lunch Mrs Ballard received a dispatch from Misses Ballard of Louisville, that they would arrive on Friday to make Mrs Bland Ballard a visit, they are the two single sisters of Blands who has just lost their Mother, Mrs Thruston Ballard went at one O, clock to take Luncheon with Mrs Donevan, and Mrs Sawyer. Paul left this morning for Chicago, but had trouble with his ticket, so returned this afternoon to our Cottage, and will go again to morrow to Chicago, to night we are all at home but Elbert, he gone to see the Wilsons, who are very fond of him, Miss Claire Wilson is Elberts favourite

Paul left for Chicago this morning.  Wednesday, August 14, 1901  Today is cloudy, but I think it will clear up. Our party here after breakfast, went over to Mrs Maloney,s to see her beautiful garden it occupies a block of ground, and their White Colonial house, three stories and basement, with large columns and a small Church or Chapel of their own. Now the party is going to swim and take their salt Bath, then Mrs Thurston Ballard is going to luncheon at Elberon, we had a delicious lunch of boiled chickens, and everything else nice Paul Harvey left at nine O. clock for Chicago, Adele went to the depot with him. Mrs Thruston Ballard and family returned to us to dinner at Six O clock then our party went over at eight O. clock to Mrs Maloney,s to see her beautiful house, Elbert gone to the Casino, We had letters to day from Ada Swearingen at Green Lake Wisconsin she very happy and well. says they play golf a great deal, and it is a beautiful place, they are very content, and wont go farther, as the illness of Mr Swearingen,s Father may call them home, any time.

Pleasure Bay. Paul will arrive in Chicago at 10, to night Thursday, August 15, 1901 Mrs A.C. Badger taken cold. More fortunes told. The morning cloudy and slight showers. until two O, clock, then the sun came out and it bids fair to be sunny. Mr Bland Ballard & wife, Mr Thruston Ballard and wife and Mr Elbert Harvey, all took Carriage and gone to Pleasure Bay, to spend the day, and Bland Jr went too, I have taken some cold, and cough some, but otherwise I sleep well, and eat well, at seven O, clock to night, our party all returned to dinner, from Asbury Park where they stopped to buy some things and have their fortune told, so the ladies came home full of excitement,  X   I wrote home to my son Shreve, Our party was delighted with the fortune Teller she told so many things that seemed real, and told them so much of their real character, she did not tell them much of the future but all about their character, and past life, which astonished them, and she also told them what they were best fitted for. it surprised them, how many things she told true about Bland Jr. he is thirteen years old, but is very large, and erect. takes 14 year old clothes to fit him,

Mr Thruston Ballard said good Bye, and gone to New York,  Friday, August 16, 1901  Misses Ballard arrived at five to day.  This is a glorious morning, last nights shower had made everything so green & fresh. We are all well. This morning early Mr Thruston Ballard left on the seven O. clock train for New York, by himself. his wife child and Nurse, will stay with us, until to morrow. at five O. clock, The Misses Ballard will arrive from Louisville, to visit their Brother, A nice letter came this morning from Mattie Badger. in which she says, Mrs Shreve Badger, Nana, Ned, and baby Shreve, will arrive and take the Cottage next to Mattie,s at Hoshkonong. My son Shreve Badger will bring them there they will stay two weeks.  It is near five O. clock, so Adele, Mr. Ballard Bland Jr, and Mrs Austin Ballard all went to the depot to get the Misses Ballard They arrived well, and in good spirits, we had dinner, very soon, and all enjoyed themselves, and we had a delightful party, after dinner all went on the porch, some played cards, Elbert Harvey went with the Misses Wilson to the Casino, to a very grand party, or German to night, gotten up by the ladies, it was a great success, Elbert stayed and danced until 4 got many favors. very handsome.

Misses Ballard of Louisville arrived at five strikeout:  today, and Saturday, August 17, 1901  Mrs Thruston Ballard & family left to day,  Today is beautiful, a lively breeze, we are all well. after breakfast, Mrs Thruston Ballard, family and maid, left at ten O clock for her Brother,s house at interlochen, Mr Creedo Harris, then they go to New York, then to Louisville, all went to the depot with them, Mr Ballard after lunch took his two Boys, to the Bay to fish, they caught seven fish, their first effort. Miss Susie Ballard played all morning for us, she is a very fine Musician, Bland Jr. is playing very well on the Piano, I wrote a letter to Ada Swearingen to day. Mrs Shreve, Adele and her boys, all received to day letters of thanks from Ada S, for her beautiful bridal gifts, Mrs Schoonmaker is ill at her Cottage from cold in her Eyes and head. she stayed too long in the Ocean, and got in her Automobile with wet hair, which cold settled in her eyes and head. she wrote to Mrs Shreve a letter of thanks for the roses she sent them, and said she was better, to night Mr. Ballard and two sisters played cards, Adele Ballard Mrs Shreve & Mr A.C. Badger all sat and talked, the wind is high, and I am afraid of a storm, the game the Ballards are interested in is Bridge Whist.

Sunday, August 18, 1901  It rained all night, and to day it has poured rain all day, Elbert & Mr & Mrs Ballard, called a stage and gone to Church, Miss Susie Ballard is reading on the porch to Bland. Jr. Miss Fanny Ballard is in her room reading. Mrs Shreve and Mrs A.C. Badger are Reading. I still have my cough, sea air has not yet made any changes in it, I will write to Mrs R. L. Henry. Elbert gone to see Misses Wilson, at their Cottage. Mrs Scoonmaker still ill with cold in her eyes, and head, the doctor thinks it is from staying too long in the Ocean, something like Malaria, and riding with her hair wet in her Automobile. She had to go to bed, and the Doctor said she might lose her eye. she suffered severely, but after a few weeks she was out again, almost as well as ever, but she had to be very careful. Then her son James took ill with fever, and had to keep bed for several weeks, and they returned sooner to Pittsburgh, and closed their cottage

Monday, August 19, 1901  This morning it poured rain, and Mrs Bland Ballard gave up her trip to New York, but at seven O,clock while they were at breakfast, the rain ceased, and they called the Stage, and Mr & Mrs Ballard rushed off for the train they were to be given a small dinner at the Waldorf by Mr & Mrs Thruston Ballard, their cousin, all the rest of us have been at home, all day, Elbert and Bland, Jr went into the Ocean, I wrote to Sheridan S. Badger to day and to his wife Gertrude.  Elbert Harvey gone to Asbury Park with the Misses WIlson, and they intend to go to the fortune Teller, at seven O, clock Mr and Mrs Bland Ballard arrived from New York, to night we had fine music from Susane Ballard and Mrs Bland Ballard, they both play so well in the Piano, their duetts very very fine. Adele has always played well. but she is so timid that she always refused. but last summer, Signor Campanari and Adele played so much music together that it gave her more confidence, so this summer she is much improved last summer after they left the Beach they went to California, and stayed all winter

Fraulien Teck sick  Tuesday, August 20, 1901  Today is sunny, and warm, all of us well, the gentlemen, Mr Bland Ballard & Bland. Jr. and Elbert Harvey all gone to take their salt bath. Misses Ballard are sewing and Mrs Shreve & Mrs A.C. Badger are writing and baby Belle Sheridan is playing on the porch, with her nurse Katie, and Shreve is taking his german lesson, from Fraulein Teck, who is with them as governess, Thunder is sounding and we will have an Electrical storm, after lunch to day, Fraulien got sick and wanted to go to her Mother, so Mrs Ballard made her girl Lizzie go with her to New York to her Mothers home, and Mrs Ballard will get another girl, Elbert will go out walking in a few moments and thinks he will go and see the Wilson, to night Mr Ballard, and his sisters are playing cards, and Mrs Shreve, and Mrs Badger are reading, Adele Ballard playing music had a letter from Paul Harvey, says Mr. A.C. Badger is visiting Mrs Harvey his daughter for a few days, and will visit Spring Lake, as soon as he can arrange his buisness, he will then visit Mrs Bland Ballard at her Cottage at Spring Lake Beach. N.J.

Letter from Mrs Ada Swearingen & One from Ada Henry.  Wednesday, August 21, 1901  Today is a beautiful sunny day. but warm, Mr Ballard, Elbert, Bland. Jr. and little Shreve, all rose early and went out in a big boat go fishing, and returned at four, O. Clock Mr Ballard caught 40 fish, Bland. Jr 30, James Schoonmaker and and Shreve caught one. Elbert caught several but Mr Houstons said they were no good so they did not bring any home To night after dinner Mr Maloney called to see us, with his oldest daughter, and we had a very pleasant evening, Elbert went to the Casino, later Mr Ballard played cards with his sisters, I received a letter from Ada Swearinger, at green Lake Wisconsin, and one from Mrs Henry of Chicago, Ada was very much pleased at this summer resort. She and her Husband played Golf. they met there many Chicago people. Their plans were to go down the St Lawrence river, and then go East, and they had promised Mrs Ballard to come to her Cottage for to spend some time with her, but the Doctor told Mr Swearingen not to go far from home, as his Father might die at any moment from another Stroke of Paralysis, or from heart failure.

Thursday, August 22, 1901  Another beautiful day, but warm, all here well. After breakfast we all sat in the Music room and listened to Miss Susane Ballard play and Mrs Bland Ballard, at eleven O. clock Miss Fanny Ballard and brother Bland, went in bathing, in the Ocean,  After luncheon Elbert Harvey and Mrs Bland Ballard went to Oil CIty to visit Miss Minara Simpson, The sweetheart of Mr Paul Harvey. Mr Ballard, and Bland. Jr. have gone to play Golf.  The Louisville Post of the 21st say that Mr George Swearingen was alarmingly ill last week but is now better. he is Ada Badgers fatherinlaw, To night after dinner Elbert Harvey called on miss Maloney, and in a little while, Elbert and Miss Maloney came over and invited us all to come over as her Father was going to light up their grounds, and she wanted us to see them Misses Ballard & Adele all went over, and in a little while Mr Dan Doneven and his sister Mary came to play and sing. for Mrs Ballard, we enjoyed their music very much, both have improved so much, Mrs Ballard treated all to Ale, Crackers & ginger ale-

Friday, August 23, 1901  This is a beautiful sunny day with a brisk breeze. We are all well. at eleven O. clock, Elbert, Miss Fanny Ballard, Mr Bland Ballard, and Bland. Jr, all went in the Ocean. Col Schoonmaker and Gretta were in also. She is just back from Pittsburgh, I had a letter from Mr Badger and he says he will be here in a day or two, much to our great surprise, Mrs Schoonmaker walked in to see us, she looks splendid and dont show her illness, she tried Electricity fo her eye, the great pain was behind the ball of the eye. She has to be careful of the wind.  at three O. clock Mr Caldwell, called for Elbert to go with him, for a horse back ride, we watched them start off, the young men looked well, the horses were black. Mr Ballard and two boys have just returned from fishing, Elbert returned from his ride with bad news, the horse he rode was all tired out and near home, he fell down prostrated from heat, and they dont know if he will die or not, Elbert jumped off, and did not get hurt, to night he went over to Wilsons,

Mrs Chas Jeannerett died Aug 18th  Saturday, August 24, 1901  A.C Badger arrived today This morning it is raining, so most of us are at home, Mr Ballard goes to Deal to day to play Golf. and Miss Fanny Ballard and Bland. Jr are out playing Golf Elbert gone to Mrs Wilson, I received a letter from Frances, and Siss had one from Mrs O. F. Badger. I has poured rain all day. at four O. clock I received a letter From Frances. and at five O. clock we received a dispatch from Philadelphia from Mr A.C. Badger, he called on Mrs L.H. Stanwood for a little while, then at five O. clock he arrived at our Spring Lake Station, Mr Ballard, Bland Jr and Shreve all went to the train and Mr Badger came up with them looking well, and in a new suit of clothes, with a light grey hat, and neck tie, he look like a New York swell. his neck tie of grey was like his hat. Mrs Charles Jeanneret dies Aug 18th nÃ©e Arianna E Mother of Charles. W. & Harry. G. Jeanneret. funeral from Residence 555. Webster, ave, (Tuesday, 1,30,

Mrs Bland  Ballard had her birthday, with a large Cake & Candles brought from Louisville. made by Mrs Solger. Today is a beautiful Sunny Morning, all of us well. We rose early, as the Misses Ballard and Bland, Jr. all wanted to go to the Catholic Church, to hear Mr Dan Donevan sing in the Choir. after they went, Mrs Bland Ballard and Elbert all went to the Presbyterian Church after the Stage drove off. We sat on the  Porch, and who should drive up but Mr Thomas W. Shreve, the only son of Mrs T. T. Shreve, he dined with us, and left for New York, at five, where he lives, he has a farm in the Suburbs, where he spends much of his time, Mrs Bland Ballard had her birthday to day. Mr Ballard Sent to Louisville for the Cake, it was a beauty, full of Candles, our dinner was fine, ice Cream and everything So good, we were eleven at table, We have had a lovely day.    After dinner we all sat in the parlor and chatted and read. Mr Badger wrote to Belle Harvey and to Ada Henry. This Cottage inside is very much like our Kenilworth home, and outside the Large Forest trees, so many around the house and the yard, so large and no fences, that it reminds me of my home, only our Forest trees are more beautiful and full.

Miss Simpson called from Oil City ( Manara)  Monday, August 26, 1901  A beautiful day, but warm. All of us in good health, Mr Badger very much pleased to be here, This morning I received a letter from Ned Badger, and one from baby Shreve. They are at Hoshkonong, Wisconsin we also had letters from Mattie Badger and little Adele, who has just has a birthday We received a telegram from Miss simpson, saying she would call on us at three, she arrived on good time, she is a very beautiful young lady, very Tall, and a blonde with handsome teeth, very fair, she is Paul Harveys sweetheart, and seems to be a very delightful young lady a Carriage came for her, and Elbert took her to the station, Mr Donevan and Mr Thunder came to see Adele, Mr Donevan sang some lovely songs, and Mr Thunder played very finely on the Piano, Mr blank from South Carolina called, our party play cards every night, Elbert gone to the Wilsons, Mr Badger Mrs Shreve and I read I wrote a letter to Mrs Hilton and Carrie Booth at Oak Park Illinois,

A. C. Badger, Mr & Mrs Bland Ballard & Miss Ballard went to Asbury Park and had their fortunes told    We have a beautiful day, cool, and bright Sun, we are well, Mr Ballard gone to  Deal Beach, all the rest of our party will some go in bathing and some go to Asbury Park. I received a nice letter from Mrs R. L. Henry of Chicago. Mr A. C. Badger, Miss Ballard, and Mrs Bland Ballard, all went to a Reader of the hand,Asbury Park, and she told their fortunes, many things were very true, and other things they doubted, they returned at two O. clock to dinner. Miss Susane Ballard after luncheon went to bed with a Severe headache and did not come to supper. Mr Badger, Mr Ballard and Miss Fannyy all played cards.   Bland Jr had a bad fall off his wheel, and hurt his arm.  Elbert gone to see the Wilson,s Mrs Wilson sent me a Newspaper, on the engagement of John D. Rockefelder Jr. it gives him such a fine character. A little boys horse turned the corner too quick and broke his leg, and they had to give him Chloroform and killed him, the little boy jumped off, and was not hurt the little boy who owned the horse was broken hearted

Miss Susie Ballard sick in bed, Mr & Mrs O.F. Badger X  , at. Kenilworth   Wednesday, August 28, 1901  This is a glorious day, all of us well. received a letter from little Adele Badger, on the train going to Chicago leaving Hoshkonong, where they have spent the summer, Frances and family who have also been at the same place, are on the train too, taking all Matties family with her to Kenilworth, to spend sometime with her, before Mattie returns to Louisville, they will have a nice time, Mr Badger & Mr Ballard. Bland. Jr and little Shreve all gone to the Beach, also Elbert, most of them went into the water, Miss Susie Ballard still in bed  I have received many visiting cards from Chicago, and Louisville, acknowledging Ada,s announcement  at four O. clock Mr A.C. Badger and Mrs Badger called on Col and Mrs Schoonmaker at their new home, Mrs Schoonmaker was out, but we made a visit with the Colonel. Elbert Harvey went out on horseback with Miss Maloney, she had two very fine horses, that are hers.

Bon, fire,        Miss Fanny Ballard has headache.  Thursday, August 29, 1901  This is a perfect day, cool and beautiful, all of us well. Elbert last evening went with the Wilson,s to the Beach, Mr Ballard spent the evening at the Casino, This morning Mr Ballard went to Deal, Miss Susane Ballards is well again, but yesterday Miss Fanny Ballard went to her bed with bad headache, and is in bed to day, Mrs Shreve has a bad eye, it is very red doctor calls is Malaria conjunctivitus, I dont know if this word is spelt right or not. we had a lovely letter from Ada Badger Swearingen, at Green Lake. says she is well, but Mr S. has bad headaches. his Father very ill, they may return home any moment. Elbert has gone driving with Misses Wilson in their Cart, A.C. Badger gone down to the Beach with little Shreve Ballard, after dinner Mr & Mrs Ballard, Miss Susie, Shreve and Bland. Jr, all went to the Beach, to see a large Bon fire and a party of boys of a club, invited four boys into the society they put masks on the four, and threw them in the Ocean, then pushed them in barrels, and then threw peices of watermelon at them and rolled them, sent up Balloons, burnt and Effigy- and called out the fire Patrol, had lots of fun

Fortunes told our party at Asbury Park.  Friday, August 30, 1901  We have another glorious day, so clear & fresh all of us well, for a few days I have had a pain in my left shoulder blade, but it is better to day. I have put on a porous plaster Miss Fanny Ballard is better again After breakfast, Mr Badger, Miss Susane Ballard Mr & Mrs Bland Ballard, all went to Asbury Park to have their hands read. They visited three places, and came back much pleased with what they were told, Mr Ballard had a type writer put down all they told him, and they gave him a good fortune, but said he had a weak heart. and nervous temperment we all know that he is nervous. Mr Badger Mr Ballard, Bland. Jr. and Shreve all gone down this afternoon to the Lake fishing, Elbert gone with Wilsons to Pleasure Bay, in their Cart. To night we had music by Miss Ballard and Elbert read us a book on Clubs. Mr Ballard, Adele and Elbert gone out. I wrote to Mattie Badger. Our moonlights are gorgeous. and the great Ocean. with its high waves. and the glorious Moon shining on it seems to speak to all, of "Gods Power".

Saturday, August 31, 1901  This was a beautiful day until four, then it became cloudy and looks like rain, This morning after breakfast we had a call from Miss Donevan, and Miss blank after they left, I went in a Carriage to the Beach, to see Miss Ballard go in the water, also Elbert and Bland. Jr.  Mr A.C. Badger went down to look on, at four, Miss Claire Wilson came in her cart for Mr Ballard, and Elbert, and Miss May, went on Wheels, and Miss Fanny and Miss Susie and Bland. Jr all went to Allaire on their Wheels. they all returned at half past seven Mr Ballard returned late; but he said he had been to Seabright. After dinner Elbert went to the Casino, and danced. Mr A.C. Badger went over to the Casino to see the dancing, I could not go on account of the pain in my shoulder, Mr Ballard and the young ladies played cards, Mrs Shreve and I talked, and read. My first visit has been a very delightful One here, but it has been a great regret to me, that I had this cold and Rheumatism in my system. so I could not sit on the Beaches, and watch the bathers.

Mr George Swearingen very ill, Bride Ada & groom called home. Sunday, September 1, 1901 To day is perfect, a real ideal day we are all well. Miss Susane Ballard went to the Catholic Church with Miss Donevan and Miss blank she enjoyed the music, Adele, Mr Ballard and miss Fanny & Bland. Jr. all went to the Catholic Church, Mrs Shreve, Mr Badger and I staid at home, Thomas W. Shreve came from New York and spent the day with his Mother and Sister, left for New York at four, After supper Mr Badger Miss Susane Ballard, Bland. Jr. Mr Ballard and Adele all went to the Casino to hear Mr Donevan sing Elbert went to the Wilsons & Casino, When all returned from Casino, we had Crackers and Ginger Ale. Adele Ballard is a fine housekeeper. and a good manager with her servants they all like her so much. that she can ask them to do things, out of their line, or give up their day, to her, and they do it most willingly. So late at night, we always had refreshments, sometimes we numbered over fifteen, and of course used many plates and glasses, but we never heard any complaints.

Mr. Stewart Bell arrived at Six.  Monday, September 2, 1901  It was cloudy until Noon, when it cleared up. all of us well, after breakfast Miss Fanny Ballard went in the stage with Miss Donevan, and Miss Ellsler to Asbury Park to a Palmist to have their hands read, and Mr Badger Mr Ballard, little Shreve and Bland. Jr. all went fishing on the inlet.  Mrs Shreve and Mrs Badger writing, Miss Susane Ballard playing her music, we expect to day Mr Stewart Bell. We had a letter from our son Sheridan, says they are all in health, and still are at Western Springs, and now getting Adele ready for her boarding school, Notre Dame in Indiana, Mr Stewart Bell arrived at six, he looks well. Misses Ballard went over and played Croquet with Miss Donevan and friends, all stayed home and played cards and read, I wrote a letter to Ada Swearingen one to Ada Henry,  Old Mrs Donevan had been quite ill for several weeks, she has brights disease, but she is such and energetic lady that she wont give up. She has a rolling chair, and a trained Nurse, Miss Donevan has a very severe cold and cough, but goes everywhere.

Mrs A.C. Badgers first walk to the Beach.  Tuesday, September 3, 1901  Mr. Bland Ballard gone fishing in Maine This has been a beautiful day all of us well. After breakfast we took a Carriage and went to the Beach to see bathers, but it was high tide, So few were in, after Lunch Mr Badger, Mrs Ballard and myself all went into the Maloney grounds opposite Mrs Ballards Cottage to look over the grounds, the gardener let us in, we walked all over the grounds, and I was amused at the beauty of the garden, which occupies one block, every variety of flowers vines and trees with ponds, one filled with the Lotus, others with rare plants, the basins with marble border, then Arches, Tunnel bowers, mounds, forest and &ccc the front of garden terraced, the white house, has four fronts with lovely porches and rare flowers, Mr and Mrs Maloney and two daughters, are the family later Mr. Badger and I went down to the Beach, and sat on the Seetee and viewed the Ocean, Mr Donevan came here this morning and Sang for us all, Miss Susan Ballard played his music, Mr Ballard left to day for Maine.

Ada Badger Swearingen letter Ida Drews Wedding  X  Wednesday, September 4, 1901  Our Weather Continues beautiful, cool & Sunny. all of us well. the Misses Ballard, Mr Bell and Elbert all gone in the Surf. then all took a Bycicle ride, Mrs Ballard and Bland. Jr. gone to Asbury Park, all the rest of us writing and reading, Buby gone to the beach, I received cards to day from Mrs E.W. Blatchfords & MIss Fanny, from Europe, we also received cards of invitations to Ida Drews Wedding in Chicago, also cards from Mrs A C. Adam, from Portsmouth, her summer home, these cards acknowledge Ada Badgers Wedding, Today we had a nice long letter from Ada at Louisville, they were all packed to visit Adele at Spring Lake Beach, when a dispatch told them that Mr George S his Father had another attack of Paralysis, they took the first train home, but fortunately had time to dine with Mrs Harvey. She dined with the bride Mrs Gilbert Cowan, then saw the conclave deceration, and dined with a party at the Country Club. Mr and Mrs Marburg, came to see us all last evening, they have a pretty Cottage near Mrs Ballards, Their Winter home is in Baltimore

Mr and Mrs George Harvey arrived to night.  Thursday, September 5, 1901  This is a faultless day, all of us in health. We are going to walk to the Beach, the young ladies are going in to bathe, so is Mr Bell, and Elbert. Mrs Shreve is reading Our Weather is most perfect. I will write little Adele Louise Badger. We expect George and Mabel Harvey to day. from Eranston, Illinois, George Harvey is the fifth or fourth son of Mr T.W. Harvey, my soninlaw who married my oldest daughter Belle Sheridan Badger, she has had seven children, and Mr Harvey had 6 (six) sons by his first wife Miss Hardman of Louisville. I think it was twenty eight years since he married Belle. She has now three sons and one daughter, (She has left, of her own) children, (I mean Belle S. Badger,) she has lost, three little girls, names, Elvira, Pauline, and Evaline, they were a severe loss to their Parents, as they were unusually attractive and good, Elvira was a little Saint, and a great christian, and church worker. She was only 12 years old. when she died.

President McKinley shot. at Buffalo.  X  Friday, September 6, 1901  Today is another beautiful day, & bathing, good, all our party gone bathing, at twelve O,clock, Mr George Harvey with his wife Mabel, called to see us they arrived from Evanston this home and have been to Newport, & New York, and several other places, they will stay here until Monday at the Hotel called the Breakers, Sunday they will drive with Mrs. Ballard, tonight they have gone to Allair, to a clam bake, given by Mr Caldwell, the party compose Mr & Mrs George Harvey, Elbert Harvey and the three Misses Wilson, at four, Mrs Ballard, George Harvey, Mr A.C. Badger & Mrs. Badger, all went over to Mrs Maloney,s to see their beautiful garden and house, all the family had  gone to Seabright this afternoon at five all Spring Lake was under intense excitement over the Shooting of President McKinley at Buffalo Exposition, there are many rumours, last Bulletin said, he had two bullets removed, had been taken to his friends house, was resting quietly. We will know better tomorrow. but he is seriously shot in his Abdomen, in two places.

President McKinleys Wound very Serious.  Saturday, September 7, 1901  Today very warm, all of us well, but my right knee is very Rheumatic, from a fall. Mr & Mrs George Harvey Elbert and Miss May Wilson all have gone to Allair to take Luncheon, Mr Donevan called today, and he and Miss Susane Ballard played and sang many opera,s, Mr Donevan saw Signor Campanari, in New York, he had just arrived from Italy. Where he and his family, have spent, their summer. he will sing in New York Opera the middle of October. after Seven O.clock dinner, Mr and Mrs George Harvey, came to see us all, we sat out on the Porch, then we came in and and Miss Susane Bullard played on the Piano. The Last Bulleton says, President McKindley is resting easy, only one bullet found, his case is serious but his pure habits will help him very much, no one is allowed to see him

Sunday, September 8, 1901  Our Weather still continues beautiful, today cool, after breakfast Elbert, Adele, Blanch Jr A.C. Badger, and Misses Ballard, all went to Church, at 12, O clock, Mr Thomas Shreve came from New York to spend the day with his Mother and Sister Mrs Ballard. at One Mr George Harvey and wife came to dinner, we had a beautiful dinner, with Champagne. Then all went on the Porch, and took pictures of our group. and sat and talked until six, then George and Mabel went to their Hotel the Breakers, and Mr Shreve went to New York. after a delicious supper we all went into the Parlour, and talked and played music, had a nice letter from Mrs RL. Henry, from Chicago.

Mr & Mrs George Harvey left for Chicago to day.  Monday, September 9, 1901  A beautiful day, all of us well, it is quite cool, after breakfast, George & Mabel Harvey spent the half morning with us, as they go on the New York, limited to Chicago, they are very pleased with their trip, which has been very extensive, they left their daughter Dorethea with Mabel,s Mother, Mrs Dr Streeter at Lake Forest, She is ten years old, and little Margery they left with George,s Father, at their beautiful home in Chicago, called Fernwood Villa, 5810 Monroe Avenue, near the University, had a nice letter from Mrs R.L. Henry. She and her family are well. and sent their love to all.  Misses Ballard gone to blank  Mrs Bland Ballard has taken a cold in her head. She brought out her Kodak, and took pictures of all our party, Mr George Harvey has his camera, and he took all our pictures in a group. he is a good Amateur Photo Maker. When he has time from his buisness, he is a fine Architect

Tuesday, September 10, 1901  It was very cloudy early this morning but at noon it cleared up. We are all in health, and talking of our winter plans I am undecided whether I will go direct to Kenilworth, or to Louisville with my Sister Mrs Shreve, and then have an opportunity of seeing my daughter, Ada Swearingen, the bride, after Lunch Mrs Shreve and Mrs Badger, dressed to go visiting, the Carriage, was at the door, and we came down in our bonnets, and when we went on the Porch we found a storm coming up, so we sent the Carriage away. and lost our visits  The whole Country is so agitated over the dreadful, and Outrageous, shooting of our President McKinley. that we can talk of nothing else, all the children seem to feel the terrible blow, telegrams have poured in from every part of the world of Sympathy.  Crowned heads have sent condolence, and sympathy there never was so much grief for a President felt. as now Mr McKinley was such a wise Christian man the whole world is plunged in Sorrow.

Wednesday, September 11, 1901  This is one of the most beautiful days of the season, cool and sunny. after breakfast all of us well. we sat on the Porch and talked Mr & Mrs blank called to say "Good Bye" as they leave at ten O,clock. for Chicago, we received a letter today from our Son Shreve, from Chicago. also a long letter from Frances with a list of Ada Swearingen gifts after marriage I will copy it also a letter from Gertrude Badger, and One from Adele Louise Badger, and one from Mrs Embry Swearingen, nÃ©e Ada Badger describing her home, and all the nice things said about her, and how happy she was, Old Mr Swearingen no better, Mrs Mattie Badger is now visiting at the home of Mrs Harvey, then she goes, to Mrs Shreve Badger, Misses Ballard gone to Asbury Park with Bland Jr.  Miss Moses brought her beautiful little Poodle to see us, all, little Shreve not well, to night so Adele Ballard sent for Dr Reeves, he says it is cold and Malaria, he has had it in his system for several years.

Thusday, September 12, 1901  This morning is cloudy but warmer, all of us well, Miss Ballard has gone on her wheel to the Express Office, Mr Donevan is here this morning, singing with Susane Ballard, all the rest of us reading paper about President McKindley We are all trying to talk over our plans of returning to our homes. Mrs Ballard will remain until late in the Fall. Received a dispatch this morning from Mr Bland Ballard that he would be home to night, from Maine, his fishing place. I think in Bangor where they had their fishing It has been raining the last two hours, and it is very damp, Little Shreve Ballard is much better to day. Miss Fanny Ballard is up to day. her head is well, but the day being rainy we have all stayed at home, to night we received another dispatch that Mr Ballard would not be home before nine to morrow. Mr Badger and I expect to go at half past seven to Philadelphia to visit Mrs T. H. Stanwood, and family. if it dont rain, had letters from Stanwood and Alpheus Badger. We went to Philadelphia, saw all the Stanwoods they are a lovely family, all grown, living at home

President James McKindley, died Sept 14.  Friday, September 13, 1901  We rose very early, dressed in haste, as we expected to go to Philadelphia to spend the day, Weather beautiful, all of us well, We had our breakfast on time, and took the stage to the depot it took two hours and a half, we arrived on time took the Cars, and went direct to Mrs I. H. Stanwoods, home Green Street, 1932. to Luncheon. found all the family, Which consists of the widow, daughters Daisy and May, 3 sons, Messers, Henry, Charles & Wendell, adopted daughter, Gertrude Richards (her Mother a very dear friend of Mrs Stanwood,s we had a delicious Luncheon, then sat, and talked until Three O. clock, then we went to the depot, and found the time table had been changed, and the last train for Spring Lake gone, so we had to return to Aunt Carrie Stanwood,s until next day, when we returned to the house, all were delighted, and we had a good laugh, we had a delicious dinner, then went into the parlour and talked and laughed, all evening, Mr Badger went with Harry Stanwood to drive to see the Park. illuminations, we all returned at eleven, O. clock

Roosevelt tool Oath for President to day.  Saturday, September 14, 1901  This is another beautiful day, all of us well. We rose at five, dressed, and went down stairs found Aunt Carrie, it was seven O. clock. She had a nice breakfast, ready for us. soon Daisy, May, Gertrude, Harry & Wendell. came down, after many pleasant remarks. we all went into the drawing room, Our whole party was plunged in gloom over the Sad and terrible news of the Presidents James McKindley dying at two, fifteen this morning, all the Doctors had given out hope that he would get well, and for a few days he did improve. but a Sudden change came and he sank rapidly, it has thrown the whole Nation, in gloom, he was such a good, and able Man, he lay in State in the City Hall at Buffalo for a day now he lies in State at the White House at Washington, all of President,s family and relations are at Washington

Memorial Services at all churches for the dead President.  Sunday, September 15, 1901  Early this morning it was cloudy, but now the sun is shining, all of us well. Telegrams are still pouring in from all parts of the world, even from Capetown Africa, to Mrs James McKindley on President McKindleys death (of Sympathy)  Mr Thomas Shreve has just arrived from New York to spend the day with his Mother, and Sister Mrs Ballard. We had a delicious dinner all the family were at dinner but Elbert, he dined with the Wilsons at five Tom Shreve returned to New York, to night all our party go to the Casino to hear Dr Willitts talk on the death of President  Lincoln This morning Misses Ballard Elbert Harvey and Mr and Mrs Bland Ballard all went to hear Dn   Mrs Judge Rearden of Kenilworth and daughter Nana spent three days at Cleveland, visiting relatives they were much pleased, and all were glad to see them, Judge Rearden,s only sister lives there she is an Old Maid,

Monday, September 16, 1901  This has been a beautiful day, warm but a good breeze, all of us well. after breakfast, we sat in the Library and talked and laughed, Mr Donevan came over and sang for us, some lovely songs, Miss Sue Ballard played for him, after lunch, Mrs Shreve and I, sent for a Carriage, and we made some Calls, first we called on Mrs Wilson and the daughters, saw them all  Mrs Claire and Elbert were going for a drive, we found Miss Donevan at home and a visitor Mrs Lill and her boy, nine years old, we found Mrs Bancroft at home, three ladies were visiting her, saw Mrs Maloney there, called on Mrs Marburg, she was out called on Mrs Schoonmaker, she was out found Mrs W-K. Brown at home, and Miss Muller, they glad to see us, Miss Muller gave me some tablets to try for my Rheumatic knee. to night our party playing cards, Dr Reeves from Philadelphia, who has a Cottage at this place, came to see Mrs Ballard, and he gave me the same Tablets, but they did no good.

To day and Night, we have had quite a Storm  Tuesday, September 17, 1901  It has been pouring rain all day, like April showers, we all rose early, as Mr & Mrs Bland Ballard, Misses Ballard and Mr A.C. Badger, were all going to New York to spend the day with Mrs Thruston Ballard, all ate their breakfast in haste it being too rainy to leave at half past seven, so they ordered another stage to leave at nine, and when all were ready they learned to their terror that the Train had been Taken off that week and we did not know that, then the rain came down, and all took their bonnets off and stayed at home, and will try to go to morrow Elbert had an engagement with the Wilson family, to go with Mr Bell, and Mr Colven and the young ladies, to Allair to have luncheon, party will number eleven, but the rain will make them postpone it, Mrs Shreve and I will write letters. To night we all stayed in the house as it rains, Elbert Harvey read a book to us all on the Monroe doctrine, and Canals, something he is writing himself it is quite an able work. Mr Bell has brought two boxes of candy.

Mrs Bland Ballard & Misses Ballard & Mr Bell, all gone to New York for to day.  Wednesday, September 18, 1901  It has been raining all day, we all rose early and took breakfast, then our party went off in the Stage to New York to spend the day. with Mrs Thruston Ballard, of Louisville, who is at the Waldorf. Mr Stewart Bell will spend a few days in New York, then return to Mrs Ballard. at seven O. clock to night Mr Ballard went to the Depot, and in a few minutes returned in the Stage with Mrs Ballard and Misses Ballard. Mrs Shreve bought a large box of candy for family and some toys for the children, we all sat in the Music  room and Adele and Susane played. I wrote a letter to Mrs Henry. Mr Badger wrote to Mr Shreve Badger. Elbert has gone over to the Wilson Cottage. Mrs blank Donevan is quite sick. Miss Jeane Bouk of Chicago is quite sick, Mrs O.F. Badger and family are now at Mrs Bouk,s making a visit and, in November the fifth, Mrs Bouk, and Miss Jeane. will go to Mrs Octavius, F, Badger,s in Louisville and stay a few weeks, and Miss Louise Bouk will come on later.

Thursday, September 19, 1901  Today is a beautiful day, quite mild, all of us well, received a nice long letter from Ada Swearingen, she is well and happy. and much pleased with her new home. says all are so good to her. and the children lovely, to day she was going to the train to meet little Margaret Card, Granddaughter of Mrs George Swearingen, she has been in the Country Mr S. is just the same and he is glad to see them all, when he is able. Mr Ballard gone to play Golf. Miss Susane Ballard in bed to day with neuralgia in her head, she was so much in the rain, while at New York yesterday, received nice letters from Mrs T.W. Harvey, she and Paul well Mr Harvey is in California, he is doing some buisiness there with his Gas plant, his son Charles has been out there for several weeks. attending to his Father,s buisiness, he took his little girl five years old, named Janet to visit her Aunts, she has been very home sick to see her Mother,s and Three Brothers.

Friday, September 20, 1901  It is very cloudy, and threatens rain, the Severe Storm that was at Charleston South Carolina has travelled all along the coast with great violence, but so far has touched us here at Spring Lake New Jersey very kindly This morning at seven O. clock. the family in the Cottage next to ours. all left for their home in Pittsburgh. Their name was Loughlin, Mother & Father, two little boys, one little five year old girl, and two servants. It still looks like rain, so all our party will stay in doors. Mrs blank Donevan very ill, Mrs Shreve received a letter from little Adele strikeout:  Ballard in Chicago, all well with them but their friend, Miss Jeane Bouk. Mattie Badger also wrote a nice long letter, saying that Miss Bouk was better, and would soon return home, then Mattie and family would go to Mrs Harveys for a week. Mr Donevan is down stairs singing for Misses Ballard, to night our party are divided, some playing cards some playing the Piano, & some reading.

Saturday, September 21, 1901  This has been a perfect day. delightful and warm, after breakfast, Mrs Badger and Mrs Shreve, walked to the Dry Store, all laughed at the immense car the children thought it a great joke to see their grandma walking down street, as she always rides, they soon returned, having bought toys for the children, Misses Clair, and May Wilsons, called in their Cart and took Elbert, and Mr Bland Ballard to drive, after breakfast Mr Donevan called and sand with Miss Susane, after luncheon Mrs Shreve & Mrs A.C. Badger went and called on Mrs Mallney, all were out but the young daughter Helen, who we saw, a pretty blonde about fifteen they will shut up. their house here and go to New York in a week, at five O. clock, Mrs Wilson and Aunt Mrs blank called to see us all. we had just returned home, so saw them and liked them, to night Mr Badger Adele Ballard & Miss Susie all went to Donevan

Sunday, September 22, 1901  A glorious day, all well, Mr & Mrs Ballard and two sons went to church, so did Elbert, at On O,clock, Tom Shreve came from New York to spend the day. it was the birthday of Mr Bland Ballard, so they sent to Louisville for a large cake full of candles, it was a beauty. we had a fine dinner, and our toasts were good, all were very gay. and happy and Mr Ballard received several gifts  At five Mr Tom Shreve returned to New York. Miss May and Claire Wilson, called with Elbert Harvey to make us a visit, and say "Good Bye". They looked lovely in their white dresses, after supper. Mr Donevan, Miss Donevan and Mrs Sill, all came in to sing and play on the Piano, at ten O. clock, Mrs Ballard gave us a Welsh rarebit, and Ale and Ginger Ale, also Olives and soft shell crabs, crackers and pickles  letters from Mattie says she is staying at Mrs Harveys, for ten days, Mattie sprained her ankle, but not very bad Miss Jeane Bouk has been critically ill but is now better, David is in Chicago, all well at Mrs Henry,s and at Shreve,s

A.C. Badger gone to Chicago ( Mr Palmer ill here at Beach.  Monday, September 23, 1901  Elbert Harvey to Boston.   Another glorious day, all well, quite warm. we all arose very early, as Mr Badger and Elbert, were going away, Mr Badger to Chicago, and Elbert to New York, and Boston for a few days in party with Mrs Wilsons family, on a pleasure trip, Elbert will be back Thursday. we Telegraphed Mrs Harvey that Mrs Shreve could not come to her for a visit now. Mrs Harvey had telegraphed Mrs Shreve to come and visit her. Mr, A.C. Badger will Lunch to day with Mrs I. H. Stanwood and family at Philadelphia, after One O. clock luncheon the Misses Ballard, said "Good Bye" to us all and both left for Philadelphia there they would meet Mr Badger start in the train, one for Chicago and the other for Cincinnati, Mrs Ballard gone to see Mrs Palmer whose Husband is dying, Mrs Donevan is better (a little).

Mrs Donevan ill, Misses Ballard gone to Cincinnati  Tuesday, September 24, 1901  A perfect day quite warm, all of us well, Mr Ballard, and Mr Bell, gone to Deal Beach Mrs Bland Ballard gone to Asbury Park and then to see Mrs Donevan, who is very ill, they will try and get her to Philadelphia on the train to morrow. Mrs Shreve gone to the stores here at the Beach, Mrs Huey, and her daughter Mrs Moses, called to see us, they leave for Spring Lake to morrow, and go to Philadelphia, Mrs Sill and her boy Louis left to day for Philadelphia, later she will go to North Carolina, her husband is in the Navy, on the ship Boutwell

Wednesday, September 25, 1901  This has been a fine day, but very windy all of us well, Mr Ballard and Mr Bell gone to play Golf. Mrs Ballard gone to see sick Mrs Donevan and Mr Palmer who is dying  after Luncheon Mrs Donevan and family all left for Philadelphia for their home, all anxious to keep Mrs Donegan quiet, as her heart is now affected they are afraid she will die on the way. Mrs blank our other next door neighbor left to day with her two boys. Mr Bell gone to Mr Marburgh,s to dinner little Bland was sick to day at 6,O clock his mother sent for Dr Reeves, he came and thinks it a cold, something like Bronchitis, he looked an my knee that is so painful, he thinks it an old hurt, with Rheumatism and to morrow will bandage it, A letter from Mrs O.F. Badger says she and family are visiting Mrs T.W. Harvey, and delighted the Misses Lunt from Denver dine there to morrow. we all had lovely letters from Mrs Harvey to visit her now

Elbert returned from Boaston. gone there with the Wilsons-  Thursday, September 26, 1901  Again we have a glorious sunny day, all well but Bland. Jr. he has taken cold and has sore throat and fever, Dr Reeves came to see him last night said it was Malarial fever, Jamie Schoonmaker has been in bed for a week with the same desease. Mr Bell and Mr Ballard gone to play Golf at Deal. Shreve and baby gone to the Beach. after Lunch Elbert Harvey arrived from Boston, well and happy, he had a delightful visit in Boston, with Mr Wilsons family. he thinks he will go to Chicago to morrow. to night Mr Ballard and Mr Bell. went to Mr Barburgh to a Card party. Miss Muller called to see us all and gave me her Card, 4011 Spruce Street, Philadelphia also Mrs Wm, H. Brown, Spruce Street

Bland Ballard. Jr in bed with Malarial fever. Elbert Harvey gone to Chicago  X  Friday, September 27, 1901  Another beautiful day, all well but Bland. Jr. who has Malarial fever. and is no better to day. my knee is just as bad as ever with Rheumatism and the fall I had on my knee a year ago I think makes it worse. but in other aspects I am well, Mrs Shreve keeps very well. at One O. clock to day, Mr Elbert Harvey will leave for Chicago to arrange for his College studies, we all regret to have him go, he is such a fine young man, and gives so much pleasure, To night in Chicago his Mother Mrs Harvey is having a dinner party and the Misses Nina and Carolyn Lunt will be there from Denver, also Mr Turlington Harvey. Jr. and his wife, I think Mr & Mrs O.F. Badger, & two daughters, Paul, and Mrs Harvey. Mr Harvey is in California Dr Reeves said to night, he thought Bland. Jr. was better. Mr Bell gave Adele Ballard a large box of Candy. Mr & Mrs Ballard and Mr Bell gone out to walk on the Lake Shore, by a beautiful moon. The sky is so clear and stars so bright, that it is almost like day.

Col & Mrs Schoonmaker left for Pittsburgh with all their family  Saturday, September 28, 1901  This morning was so beautiful, and sunny, but at noon it is clouding, and looks like rain, all well but Bland. Jr. he feels a little better. I wrote a letter to Mr Badger. We received one from Mattie Badger, she still at Mrs Harveys afterwards will visit Mrs Shreve Badger at Kenilworth, Mrs R.L. Henry also has several guests. all afternoon it has been looking like rain, wind high, Ocean with high waves, boisterious, but late to night we have no rain, we all sat in the Parlour after dinner and Adele played on the Piano, and we all ate candy I wrote a letter to Belle Harvey. also wrote a note to Miss Muller, at Mrs Brown,s, Rev Candy and his wife left for Philadelphia, she is Mrs Browns daughter Mrs Brown has a nice cottage at Spring Lake Beach, she is Sister to Mrs Wells, who has a beautiful Cottage here. They are not at all alike Mrs Wells is all society, and Mrs W. K. Brown is so domestic and exclusive, very lovely in her Character and so sweet to her friends & family

Mr. Palmer died to day here at Spring Lake, he lived in Newark.  Sunday, September 29, 1901  To day has been foggy and damp with light rain, all well but Bland Jr. he is a little better, but coughs hard, Dr Rives comes every day. Mr Tom Shreve did not come from New York, as the day was bad. Mr Palmer died to day at strikeout: five in the morning at his cottage, he is to be buried in Newark, his home.

Mattie Belle & family leave. French Lick Springs for Louisville  Monday, September 30, 1901  This has been a glorious bright day, all of us well but Bland, who has a bad cold, I wrote to Mr Badger also to Ada Swearingen, Mrs Ballard went to Mrs Palmers to find out about Mr Palmers funeral. he will be buried Wednesday at eleven at blank all our friends are leaving for their homes, Casino is closed music gone, and so many Cottages closed, Adele wont leave here before) with her family until the fifteenth, or perhaps later.
