Tuesday, October 1, 1901  Another glorious day, all well but Bland Jr he is better, at half past seven, we all came down to breakfast, us Mr and Mrs Bland Ballard and Mr Bell all went up to New York, to spend the day, Mr Stewart Bell will not return, but spend a few days in Philadelphia and Baltimore, then go to Louisville, Mr & Mrs Ballard will return to night,  Dr Reeves called to see Bland, and says he is better, and he wont come again, my knee quite troubles me. I wrote to Shreve and Frances, Dr Reeves has given me a bottle of Pills to take for the Rheumatism of my knee, I am on the second bottle but dont feel improved yet. Adele,s little baby named Belle Sheridan after her Grandmother, is a very fine child, very large for her age, I think she is one year and a half old, very strong, and athletic, fond of outdoor sports, just like her Father, who is fond of Hunting, Fishing, Golf and all the sports.

Wednesday, October 2, 1901  It looks like rain, it is so cloudy, but it did not rain, is a little cooler. All well, Bland Jr better of his cough, got up and dressed to day. at eleven O.clock, Mr & Mrs Ballard went to the funeral of Mr Palmer. So many cottages have gone away that very few were at the funeral they closed their cottage and took him to Newark New Jersey. We all stayed at home to day and wrote and read. I wrote to Mr Badger to night and sent him a piece that said Mr Shafroth had returned from Manilla. I see by the paper that Mrs Foraker,s daughter, Miss Florence, is to be married to Mr Randolph Matthews on Nov 14. She is Senator Foraker,s daughter of Washington, D.C.

Thursday, October 3, 1901  Early it sprinkled a little, but now it is clear and sunny. All of us well Mrs Ballard, and husband, goes to New York on the nine O.clock train Bland Jr,s cough is better, I will write to day to Sheridan and Gertrude, and if I can find time to Adele Louise, their daughter. I received a letter from my daughter Mrs Embry Swearingen, she has been ill for a week, with high fever and sore throat, Doctor called it Tonsilitis, but is now much better, but I am afraid she will lose her dinners and the invitations in three boxes to the horse, how I wrote to Ada to make her feel better, a long letter, Mr & Mrs Ballard arrived at seven, from New York, they went to the Waldorf for Luncheon there the met so many Louisville friends, returning from their summer Outing, some from their Cottages others from abroad, all so glad to see each other, looking so well.

Friday, October 4, 1901  This is a perfect day, all well, but Bland Jr he is better of his cough. My sister Belle received a letter from Mr Allen Houston, says they are settled in their house, and just waiting for her and me, to visit them, Their daughter Belle Houston, has just entered society, I have so many invitations to visit my relations, that I don't know who to visit first, they love to have Mr Badger, and say I must make him come. but buisness keep him in Chicago he has an Office in my son Sheridan,s building, he is retired from active Buisness, but has interest in two gold mines that keep him watching them, and corresponding with the men at the mine, he also takes a great interest in the Printing Office of his two Grand Sons, Stanwood Badger, and Alpheus, C, Badger. They do a good buisness, have all the work they can attend to, and are first class Printers, they began very early in life, First with a Toy printing Machine, then a larger one, and printed tiny papers, after they finished school, they bought several Machines, and commenced work for a living --

Paul Harvey sent telegram to Mrs Ballard about Mr Dwights house at Lake Forest.  Saturday, October 5, 1901  This is a beautiful day, cool and sunny all of us well, Bland. Jr. is better but has not yet left his room. Mr Ballard is going early to play Golf at Deal. Mrs Shreve woke up with a severe headache. my knee very stiff on my right side from Rheumatism, I hurt it a little a year ago, and now the Rheumatism has set in much to my regret. Mrs Bland Ballard is in a great study she is trying to decide, what to do her children suffer so much from Malaria that Adele is very loathe to return to Louisville, and have the children sick all Winter, but she has not yet decided what place to go, she wanted to go to Chicago, and take a house for the winter and put the boys in school and try that climate to break up the Malaria, but Mr Ballard dont to go to Chicago, he hates the town, A telegram came to Mrs Ballard to day, saying she could rent the handsome house of Mrs Dwight,s at Lake Forest for seven Months, all furnished

Mattie Faulds Badger, Sprained her Ankle,  Sunday, October 6, 1901  Today has been beautiful and sunny but a very brisk wind, all well, Bland. Jr. much better, but still in his  none of us went to church, at twelve O.clock, Mr Thomas Shreve came from New York and Spent the day here with his Mother Mrs Shreve and sister Mrs Bland Ballard, and his Aunt Mrs A.C. Badger, we all enjoyed a delicious dinner, at five O.clock Mr Shreve returned to New York. Mrs Maloney sent a large Boquet of Flowers, to Mrs Ballard Mattie Badger sent us a letter telling us how she sprained her Ankle, she was at Church, and her foot went under her, when she stood up, and twisted her ankle, she has been unable to stand on for some weeks. had to be carried up and down the stairs while at Mrs Harveys, by her Coachman,  Dr Lundgrin, rubbed Mattie,s foot every day, for sometime, it is much better, she can put it to the ground it is singular, we three should all be hurt first time in life, Mrs Shreve hurt her foot, my daughter my Ada Badger all right

Mrs A.F. Badger & family at Mrs Shreve, Badger,s
Monday, October 7, 1901
A glorious day, balmy, and no wind, all well. We are still here at Spring Lake Beach. my knee is still stiff, from Rheumatism Bland. Jr. is much better, only a little head cold left. Mr Ballard and Adele gone down to the Beach. A letter received this morning from Mrs A.F. Badger, says she is at my sons house in Kenilworth, Illinois, making them a visit, with her Husband and two daughters, her foot is better, she has taken off her bandage. but has to be very careful. on Wednesday she will leave Mrs Shreve Badger,s and go to Mrs Boaks, on the south side, Mrs Bland Ballard is complaining of Malaria with fever and cold stages, and feels very miserable, but is still keeping up and going about, Adele is packing many boxes to leave at Spring Lake, and several trunks to go to her home in Louisville and many trunks to go to Lake Forest. so she is busy. and this Cottage is to be papered and painted for next summer, Adele thinks she will take it for another summer-

Tuesday, October 8, 1901
This has been a Sunny fine day, but very windy, Bland. Jr. walked out for a little while, first for two weeks. he is almost himself. Mrs Bland Ballard has cold and Malarial fever, she has not gone to bed yet. She is trying to keep up. Mr Ballard spent his day at Deal Beach playing Golf. To night Mr Hamilton called to see the Ballards to day Good Bye. he is a Banker in New York. a young man, very Tall and courtly. had a letter from Mr A.C. Badger I wrote to Mr Badger to day. All day I have collected together my clothes, and packed many things away. and I Think now we will leave here Monday the 14. for Louisville Ky. Dr Reeves sent me to day my bill, for giving me medicine for my knee. it was four dollars, I paid it. Mr Philip Stewart, who married Miss Fanny Cowles of Chicago (Mr Alfred Cowles, Sr & daughter) Mr Philip Stewart, is now at the White House, as the guest of President Roosevelt. They both were off Twice this Summer, Hunting together in Colorado.

Belle Sheridan Ballard born in (the Baby)  Wednesday, October 9, 1901  Today is beautiful, Sunny. and no wind, Mr Bland Ballard and Shreve have gone to the Beach on their Wheels. Bland. Jr. is well again, and been out once,  Mrs Ballard is feeling very bad with her Malaria it is clouding up. Baby Belle Sheridan, has gone to the Beach, she can talk everything well, and walks finely. has many teeth. After dinner to night, Mr Ballard read to us a book called, Elizabeth. it is full of wit, and humour, and Elizabeth is a case, we have laughed, until it almost made us sore. This spring Lake is a lovely restful place, you can be very gay, if you wish, or as quiet as one pleases, we have enjoyed all our friends very much, there are so many beautiful Cottages and good churches, and we are so near Philadelphia and New York, that we can run up there, and make our purchases and be back for six O. clock. dinner, which makes quite a frolic.

Bland Jr & little Shreve well again, out on their wheels,  Thursday, October 10, 1901  Again we have a lovely day, all well. except Adele, she is a little better. Bland. Jr. is himself once more. We have packed our trunks, all ready for a start on Monday. We will leave the Sea Side with a great deal of regret, we have had such a charming summer, it has been such a privilege to have the pleasure of all being together, my sister Mrs T.T. Shreve, is the only living member of our own family, on both sides of my Mother,s and Father,s Adele is my neice (Mrs Shreve,s daughter, and for thirteen years, she has had her Cottage at this Spring Lake Beach New Jersey- and she always wants her Mother, and me (her Aunt Elvira) with her, and all the Cousins, and Aunts, every summer, her house is full of guests beside relations, Mrs Ballard entertains very handsomely, with the best of linen glass, China, and silver, Table filled with flowers, and a polite good looking Butler almost white, and Henrietta the Cook. (who is coloured) gives us the most delicious Breads of many kinds, a real fine cook.

Friday, October 11, 1901  Today is cloudy, but warm, and looks now at noon, as it it would clear up. Mrs Shreve has gone to the store to make some purchases. Mr & Mrs Ballard gone to the Beach, the children out on their Wheels, I wrote a note to Dr Reeves and sent him four dollars to pay for my Medicine he gave one for Rheumatism in my knee. first Rheumatism I ever had, although I have lived on the Lake front since sixty one. and another remarkable thing, I never had on flannels, all these years only cotton underclothes. and did not suffer with the cold. and never had colds, but I never was imprudent neither sat at open windows in a dra or on Porches, nor slept with windows at night blowing on me . nor went out in bad weather, but was very careful to well wrap up My children also kept very well. through all our severe winters. The Ocean is in a wild state to night, the rushing and roaring can be heard three blocks away. it is a gorgeous sight to look upon. it is sublime.

Saturday, October 12, 1901  It has been cloudy, but did not rain until ten O clock to night. then very little, Mr Ballard went to Deal to play Golf. we all stayed at home and packed our trunks A letter from Mrs Houston says she wants us to come, and make her a visit, She has a nice room for us, her daughter Belle Houston who is a debutante this winter is having a grand time in Society and going to many parties, and Opera Box party Mattie Badger wrote to day, that she was still at Mr Shreve Badger,s and to morrow will go to Mr Bouk,s she is having a lovely time and dont want to come home, yet Mattie,s foot is better of the sprain. Dr Lundgrin will rub it, and Mrs Bouk is so careful that she will watch Mattie, Miss Jeane Bouk is at home again, Shreve,s family are all well. Edwin, SHreve Jr and their Cousin Nana, are all in school and Kenilworth. We have very nice Churches and schools. but no stores are allowed, but we have so many towns near us, that the carts bring all one wants-and our telephones do the rest.

Mrs Shreve & Mrs A.C. Badger still at Spring Lake  Sunday, October 13, 1901  It rained all night, and this morning is very damp, and Showers every little while but it is warm, the Ocean is beautiful so wild with such high waves, we have so far, had no big storm, this season but everything is now being closed,  the Drug store will close this week. Mrs Palmer who buried her husband some weeks ago, in Newark, has returned here for a visit with Mrs Caullis, Mrs Maloney came over yesterday to say Good Bye to Mrs Ballard, she has closed her Marble Palace, which occupies a block of ground, the house is White with large veranda,s and white columns from the porch to the top of the house, which is four stories and Attic, all elegantly furnished, and a lovely Chapel with lights burning in it at all the time, there are fifty furnished bedrooms in this house, she has closed it, and goes to New York Mr Tom Shreve came from New York and spent the day with us. To night is very stormy, raining, and blustering but not cold. we are so comfortable in this house, it is all heated by steam, and open grates beside.

Ada Swearingen has been ill with Tonsilitis in Louisville  Monday, October 14, 1901  It poured rain all night, and has continued to do so until noon, but it looks now as it if might clear up. we were all ready in our travelling dresses, and Satchel,s and down to breakfast early, but the rain fell in such torrents, that Mrs Ballard begged us to put off, our trip for Wednesday. so here we are at Spring Lake for a few days more. it is quite warm. I had a letter from Mr Badger this morning. He says he had a letter from Ada Swearingen and she has had a serious time with her throat, a severe case of Typhoid fever. and been confined to her bed. went down stairs first time this week. the doctor gave her too large a dose of Calomel. and she has had a dreadful time with her gums and mouth. she still has to only drink liquids, as her mouth is too sore to eat. The Dr says she must never take medicine like Calomel again, as it is a poison to her. she is slowly getting well. but her gum is still very swollen. lucky for Ada. she is in such good hands, Mrs Swearingen sr is such a lovely woman, she spent nights with Ada, so she might get her medicines faithfully.

Mr & Mrs Ballard gone to New York  Tuesday, October 15, 1901  This is certainly a beautiful day balmy and warm. yesterday was such a contrast raining all day, and so chilly, and gloomy. all well to day. at eight O.clock this morning Mr & Mrs Ballard went to New York for the day. we expect to leave to morrow at Noon for Louisville, I wrote to day to Mrs R.L. Henry my daughter at Chicago I have been all morning selecting presents for the servants, which number, 1 butler and four girls, and also for the two boys and to baby Belle Sheridan. Adele Ballard brought from New York for her Mother and me, very pretty silk neck peices, if  John Drake. Jr. bought my house 2106 Calumet ave, and had Torn it down to the ground, and has built up a new red brick, it is next to his Mother,s, Lillian Drake Farmum has built herself a handsome new home on Prairie Avenue. she and her husband have just returned from Europe. Mrs Drake,s oldest son, has a fine hand given him by gift, his name is Mr Tracy Drake, Frances youngest son married & living at Cleveland.

Traveled all afternoon on Cars and night to Louisville Mrs Shreve & Mrs. A.C. Badger  Wednesday, October 16, 1901  Again we have a charming day, so bright and warm. all of us well. Mrs Ballards French girl who teaches the children both German and French, went at eight O.clock to New York. to say good bye to her family, as she is going to Chicago with them, for the winter,  We finished our packing early this morning and came down to an early Luncheon that Mrs Ballard had for us, and also a box she prepared for us to take with us on the train to Louisville, with chicken buttered rolls, Olives, Lemons, Crackers, Peaches, bottle of cold Tea, and c c c  at 12,30, O.clock, the stage called for us, and with Mr & Mrs Ballard and Bland Jr. and Shreve, we all went to the depot. there we met Rev Dr Willetts, who we were glad to learn was going to Philadelphia, Our train was on time, we said the last good bye, and off we started. We changed Cars at Trenton, and had a long walk in depot, got in the Car and reached Philadelphia about three O.clock, sat in the depot until four, and then took the Pullman Car had Berths opposite to each other.

Mrs Houston made us, come to her house for a visit, X  arrived today at three, O.clock, at Louisville  X  Thursday, October 17, 1901  Thursday morning, it is a beautiful day and we feel very well, had very comfortable berths, and as no one was with us we spent a good night, I don't sleep well on the train, it poured rain in the night, so had no dust. we went in the dining Car, and had a good breakfast. then we travelled along, very smoothly, the fields and gardens all along the route were so beautiful with their Autumn foliage of every hue. and thanks to a kind Providence we arrived in safety, and quite well, about three O.clock, there at the depot, was Mr & Mrs Houston, David and my daughter Ada Swearingen who has been ill, with high fever. which threaned Typhoid, but she escaped that, but was salivated from Calomel. but now she is out again, but still has a sore mouth, we got in the Carriage and went right up to Mrs Houstons house, to dinner, we had sent our trunks to Mrs Shreves house but Mrs Houston, sent for the trunks and we will stay here a few days,

Mrs T  Friday, October 18, 1901  This morning was beautiful, we arouse early after a good sleep, all well, went to breakfast and then all met in the Billard room and talked of our summer trips.  the Butler brought up a note from my daughter Ada Swearingen, wishing me to come and take Lunch with her, and Mother Swearingen. I went and stayed until four O.clock. had a lovely visit, and nice Luncheon, our party was only, Ada, Mrs Swearingen and myself. at four my sister Mrs Shreve called for me in a Carriage, and took me to Mattie Belle Houston, where we will stay a few days longer. at half past six, Ada Swearingen and Mr Swearingen came in, to let us see her gown, before she went to the dinner given to her by Mrs Andrew Cowan at seven O.clock Mr & Mrs John Noyes. came by invitation to dinner at Mrs Houstons (where we are)
Mr Houston went to Nashville Tennessee. to night to play a game of Golf. A letter from Mattie Badger came to day saying, she, and her family would be here Sunday Morning, Mr John Noyes stayed here to night to protect us, as Mr Houston is away

Saturday, October 19, 1901  Again we have a beautiful warm sunny day, all of us well. We spent a lovely night, feeling so safe, as Mr Noyes stayed all night, as we had no Gentleman in the house, as Mr Houston was away, and David Badger Badger (who was staying here, while his Mother was away) had gone over to New Albany to visit Mr Henry, his friend. We expect Mr & Mrs O.F. Badger and family Sunday morning from Chicago, has invited the whole party here to spend the day. So Mrs O.F. Badger can get her large house heated and warm, Mrs Houston will go to the train in the morning for Mattie and party. To night Mr Swearingen and Ada came to dine with us, they staid until eleven O.clock, and seemed to enjoy themselves, both laughed a great deal. and we had a delicious dinner, Mr Houston is expected to night from Nashville, David is here staying, until his mother arrives from Chicago.

Mrs O. F. Badger and family arrived at nine, O. clock from Chicago  Sunday, October 20, 1901  Today is balmy sunny and warm, all of us well, we all arose early, dressed hastily so as to meet, Mrs O.F. Badger and family they arrived safely, and we had a nice breakfast, all were well, and they stayed here at Mrs Houston all day. and they were so happy to see us all, Mrs Shreve ordered her Carriage to come here, and take all Mattie s family to their house Mrs Shreve,s horses have just come in the the Country, Mrs Badgers family are Mr & Mrs Badger, David, Belle and Adele we just Telephoned them and they say They found everything right, and They arrived home safe. and they also said that they left all of my family in Chicago well, and Mrs TW. Harvey all ready for Mrs Ballard, and family, to come and make a visit with her children she says Mrs Henry and family are quite well. so is Mrs Shreve, Badgers family well. after our Luncheon to day. Mr & Mrs Embry Searingen called to see us, with their three children, Lalla & George & Margaret Curd the neice, they staid awhile and then returned to their home. to night Mr Churchill Mr Robinson, & Mr & Miss Bridgeford & Mr Hill called to see Belle Houston, Belle gone with Mr Stofer to make some calls.

Monday, October 21, 1901  This morning was very cloudy, but now the sun is coming out, and it promises to be a beautiful day, warm and sunny all well here but Mrs Shreve and I, who have colds, in our heads, and throats, but not sick,   Mattie Badger and family, telephoned that they rested well last night in their home on Walnut Street, 527. and all feel fine this morning Mattie has Mrs Shreve,s Carriage, and will take her children to school. they have been at the Lake, all summer. and part of the time in Chicago to day after school, Belle & Adele Badger came to see us, for a little while, at four O.clock, Mrs Shreve took a CoupÃ© and went to her house on Walnut Street and sixth, and got some clothes. at seven O.clock, old Mrs Wm B. Belknap and Miss Lucy Belknap came over to Mattie, Belle Houstons house to seven O.clock supper. We had a delicious dinner. after, we all sat around and talked and Mattie Belle made us scream at her funny stories had a letter from A.C. Badger.

Mrs A.C. Badger & Mrs Shreve & Mrs Houston all took lunch at Mrs Swearingen  Tuesday, October 22, 1901  This is an ideal day, all of us well (except me my ugly cough still holds on. and my knee Cap stiff. but I am not sick,  Last evening we had a charming time with Mrs Belknap and Miss Lucy Mattie Belle kept us screaming with laughter at her experience with the coloured man, who did her work, when she unpacked all her furniture, he was very good natured, but stuttered badly, Mattie is a fine mimic, and we almost died with laughter. Mrs Belknap is over eighty, but she enjoyed it all, they live next door to Mattie. I received two letters, one from Ada Henry and one from Gertrude Badger, they were sent to Spring Lake New Jersey. I was glad to get them, Ada is in good health. Today Mrs Shreve, Mrs O.F. Badger and Mrs A.C. Badger, all are invited to a Luncheon at Mrs G.W. Swearingen, 218 West Broadway. She is mother-inlaw of Ada Badger. Mrs Shreve, sent to her house, and got her Carriage, and we all with Mrs Allan Houston went to the Luncheon. there we met Mrs Gilbert Cowan, she is Mr Swearingen,s grand daughter (a bride) we had a charming Luncheon, and a handsome table. full of good things.

Dr Knueller called to see me for my cough & knee.  Wednesday, October 23, 1901  This is a real summer day, quite warm all here are well but Mr Houston and myself. he was sick with cramp I have a hard cough, and my knee still stiff on the knee joint. To day at One, Belle Houston will have 8 young ladies to Luncheon, invited to meet Miss Jennie Warren. who lives out of the City. Mrs Shreve and I will go, and lunch with Mrs O.F. Badger - on Walnut and Center. Mr Bland Ballard sent a letter this morning to Mattie Belle, thanking her for her invitation to come to her house, his family now in Chicago visiting Mrs Harvey, for a few weeks. Mr Ballard will stay at Mrs Shreve,s house 527 Walnut Street. At 12 O.clock Mrs Shreve sent for a Carriage and we went to the Luncheon of Mrs Badgers, had a delightful Luncheon, Ada Swearingen came and spent afternoon with us, she is well again, our party consisted of Mr & Mrs O.F. Badger, David, Belle & Adele Mrs Shreve and myself. we returned at five in the Carriage. Mrs Shreve sent for Dr Knueler to help my cough and my knee. he says it is Rheumatic and gave me medicine. and says it will help me.

Flora dined at Mrs Allan Houston,s & Mattie, David took his mother home in her Carriage  Thursday, October 24,1901  Another warm Summer day, sunny & beautiful. all well here to day, but me, my cough still troublesome, my knee much better. Mr Houston is up, and well to day. Yesterday he stayed in bed all day suffering pain but seems all right to day. At noon, Belle Houston went to a Luncheon at Mrs Logan Murray,s given to Belle. Mattie Belle went to see Mrs Todd, the old lady, to night at Seven O.clock. Mrs Russell Houston, took dinner here with her Motherinlaw Mrs Allan Houston. She is dressed in black for her baby. It is very becoming to her. Mrs O.F. Badger and David, came to dinner with Flora Houston, and we had a very enjoyable evening. about nine O clock Mr Carrington (or Prof of Latin at the blank called for Belle Houston to go to blank, and after to a dinner,  Prof Carrington we met last summer at a dinner at Mr Bland Ballards, and we were much pleased with his manners. this summer, he spent abroad. Mr & Mrs Ross Todd (the bride Miss Menefee) called to night to see Mrs Houston, Mrs Shreve and I went down to see her, she looked handsome Mr Houston took Flora home To Mrs Pattersons

Mr Bland Ballard arrived this morning from Chicago, they visiting Mrs Harvey X he alone  Friday, October 25, 1901  This is like a summer day, so warm & sunny all well but one, my Cough bad like Bronchitis, my knee better.  Mr Bland Ballard arrived this morning from Chicago, where the family have been visiting Mrs T.W. Harvey. Mrs Ballard will come to Louisville on Monday to get her clothes to visit again, Belle Houston saw Ada Swearingen at the Theatre last night and she looked well. To night Mr Ballard will take dinner with Mrs Houston, and will sleep at Mrs Shreve,s house and take breakfast at his sisters (the Misses Ballard) he is alone.  Ada Swearingen came to see us all this morning, in her tan suit, she looked, very well. Could not stay to Lunch, as she expected her husband home to Lunch. Mattie Belle gone to see Mrs Moore, Belle unclear going to a Dancing class party Ada showed me a letter from her Uncle Shreve Miss Eliza Nock called to see me, an old friend I knew when young. I was out. her father was Dr Wm Nock, he kept a drug store. and had a large family of sons and daughters

Saturday, October 26, 1901
Another, warm, sunny beautiful day, all here as well, but me, I think my cold is better, but I have declined going out. Ada Swearingen came to see us, early this morning, and stayed until one O.clock, then she left for her house, to go out and play golf with her husband. she is very fond of blank, her invitations are coming in so fast for entertainments, that she has to send many regrets. Mr Ballard took breakfast with us but seems much pleased with Chicago. Mrs Shreve ordered a Coupe, and is gone to her house 527 Walnut Street to give some orders. She is not through yet with her visit to Mattie Belle. who has been keeping house for blank years, and this is the first time she has had a chance to stay with Mattie, her house is being well cleaned, and put in order for her. it will be ready in a few days. Flora Houston, called this afternoon to  see us all, she looked very pretty in her mourning, for her 6 months old baby. She says her Father,s new wife is in, Mr Ballard has gone out to stay all night at Mr Thurston Ballards, to go Coon hunting, with a large Parry

It was Oct 27th when I took a hard cold in the stream train
Sunday, October 27, 1901
Again the sun shines brightly, and it is quite warm. all in good health, my cough is better, and my knee much better. Mrs Houston has invited Mrs Moore, Mr Jacob (John) and, regret Mr Bloom to dinner, regret
Our party consisted of Mr & Mrs Houston Belle and Allan. Mrs Shreve and Mrs A.C. Badger, Mr Bland Ballard. Mr Courtney, Mr Ackers, and Mrs Sherley Moore. Belle and Mrs Houston had many Gentlemen callers, this afternoon after supper Belle had many callers some young Ladies called too, Mr & Mrs Swearingen called after supper and stayed a long time. Ada looks well now. and seems very happy. Talks of taking a class of scholars in her Sunday school. My cough is ugly to night. it holds on so strong. Last winter I had it at Kenilworth, I went to Oak Park to see Mrs Heilton, the Steam Cars had every window open. the wind poured through I took cold, and it holds on, I have been very free from coughs. before

Mr Daniel Goodwin died
Monday, October 28, 1901
This is another lovely warm day. all well here but me, my knee is much better, but my cough holds on, Mrs Shreve has gone in a Coupe to her house 52 Walnut. St see the workmen whi are getting her house in order. for Mrs Bland Ballard who has been visiting her Cousin Mrs T W. Harvey. she arrives in the morning, with her two boys, and Governess, her baby and nurse Katy Flannergan, will stay with Mrs Harvey until Adele, returns, Mrs Ballard has rented for 7 months, Mrs John Dwights house and large grounds, all furnished with everything 3 Cows, horses, and Teams Carriages, and Coachman and Gardener. Mrs Ballard has sent to Philadelphia for the Butler, his wife, and her Cook Henrietta all to come to Lake Forest at once, she had these servants, at her Spring Lake home in New Jersey. They will be fixed beautifully, and they have most excellent schools there and fine churches, I think the Dwights are going abroad with their debutante daughter Florence. Tonight Mr & Mrs Austin Ballard and Bland Took dinner with us. David came to see us. Belle, and Albert Willis gone to the Theatre.

Tuesday, October 29, 1901
Our weather still continues beautiful warm and sunny. all well here Mrs Shreve gone to her house, to see how the workmen are coming on with the cleaning, Mr Bland Ballard took his breakfast, and will take dinner with us, Ada Badger Swearingen spent the morning with us, she well and looks handsome and happy. at four O.clock she receives with Mrs Gilbert Cowan, (the bride) in her new house. Belle Houston has gone to the Reception Mrs Allan Houston gone this afternoon. with Mrs Sherley Moore, in her handsome Cart and beautiful span of horses to look at a summer house, she thinks of buy. it belongs to Mr Atherton the name of the place is blank
Last night Mr and Mrs Embry Swearingen had a dinner given them at the Country Club, by Mr blank they drove out in a Buggy. and had a good time, and met many relatives, of Mr Swearingen,s. They called on Ada Swearingen to play and sing. all admired her voice, she had many compliments

Mrs Bland Ballard two sons and Governess, arrived this morning from Chicago
Wednesday, October 30, 1901
Mrs A.C. Badger goes today to Mrs TT Shreves house. This is a perfect day warm and sunny. all of the family well here, my cough holds on, last night was the first time it annoyed me during the night. the oppression is on my chest my lungs are so full. We rose early, and the Carriage came for Mrs Shreve, to go and meet her daughter Mrs Bland Ballard, her two boys and Governess all from Chicago. This is a busy day for the Houstons, two or three Receptions Lunches, dinners, and drives, and a Ball to night, Mrs Houston is in mourning for her Husbands Mother, and only accepts the Drives, at twelve O.clock Mrs Shreve will send her Carriage for me, to go to her house, and see the Ballards. I will take my trunk with me, and finish my Louisville visit there at my sisters, and return to my home in Kenilworth Ill. where my husband awaits me. I am invited to day to a Reception at Mrs W.B. Belknap,s to meet Mrs blank from California. My daughter Ada Swearingen will meet meet me to day at Mrs T.T. Shreve,s I cannot stay at her home this visit, on account of the critical illness of her Father in law.

Ada Swearingen Halloween party for her children to night. 
Thursday, October 31, 1901
To day is very warm, with a bright sun. all well here but me, my general health is good, only my severe bronchial cough and my lungs so full of mucous. Bland Jr. has gone by invitation to Mr Thurston Ballards Flour Mills to see them, and spend the day with him, Mrs Ada Swearingen called this morning to invite, the two Ballard boys, Allan Houston and Mrs A.F. Badgers two daughters Belle and Adele to a Halloween party to night to meet her, children, Lalla George, and Margaret Curd. Our old black woman, who lived with us in Chicago died to day of dropsy. we will send some flowers (Rachel) her name Adele Ballard so crowded with company callers, she can't unpack, to return to Lake Forest, her new winter home, Flora Houston staying some days at her Mother inlaw, Houston, she will soon go to Paris Tennessee. She will also stay at her sisters, Prof Patterson then she stay some days at her Father,s Mr Abner Harris, her brother, about fourteen years, is at home with his Father and with his step mother

Friday, November 1, 1901
More beautiful weather, warm and sunny, but not so healthy, Diptheria seems very bad they are talking of closing the schools. Mrs A.F. Badger has kept her children home to day. all of us well, my cough still holds on, but otherwise I am well. Mrs Ada Swearingen spent the morning with us, she has taken cold in her head. to night she and her husband take dinner with Mrs Allan Houston to meet Mrs Russell Houston, on account of my cough. I have sent my regret to the dinner, at seven O.clock Mrs Shreves Carriage came to the door, and Mr & Mrs Ballard, & Mr & Mrs A.F. Badger went to the dinner, Mrs & Mr Embry Swearingen were there and Flora Houston, and Belle Houston they had a fine dinner, and returned home at Eleven, O.Clock. We had at our dinner, David Badger, his sister Belle and Adele, Bland Jr, Shreve, Mrs Shreve and Mrs A.C. Badger. Emma is our waitress, I had two nice letters from Mr A.C. Badger, and an invitation from Mrs Horatio May to me to come to the dedication services at Rose Hill, of the Memorial Chapel, to her Husband Mr H.N. May, Nov 1st 1901. being in Louisville, I sent sincere regrets.

Wrote to Mrs H.N. May
Saturday, November 2, 1901
It is unusual to have so many warm and sunny balmy days together, many well here, but little Shreve Ballard has a bad cold, so his mother sent for Dr Knuellar, he says it is Malaria and Bland, Jr. has not been well since he had his Bronchal cold and fever at Spring Lake Beach. he went to day to dine with his Aunts, Misses Ballard, while there he had a chill, and little fever, his mother took the Carriage and went for him, but as soon as he saw his Mother, he felt all right to night Mrs Shreve had a family party. Mr & Mrs. Alan Houston, Mrs Russell Houston, Mr & Mrs A.F. Badger, David Badger, Mrs A.C. Badger Mr & Mrs Bland Ballard, and Mrs Shreve were our party, we had a delicious dinner, we all went into the Parlour and sang, at ten O.clock Mrs Shreve,s Carriage came to the door and Mr & Mrs Houston, took Flora to the depot, and she left for Paris Tennessee where she will meet her husband.

Mrs Alan Houstons Main St Stone burned down, on Nov 2nd
Sunday, November 3, 1901
Very early the sun shone, but from ten O.clock, it commenced raining, and its still continuing all day. None of us have gone out, but Mr & Mrs Ballard took the Carriage and went out to dine with Mr & Mrs Austin Ballard, returned at five, they have one boy, named Austin Mrs Shreve had all of Octave Badger,s family to dinner. I wrote a postal to Mr Badger. Last night near morning, the large stone of Mattie Belle Houston burned all out, I think she had insurance on it. Mattie Badger expects Mrs Boak and daughter Miss Jeane the first of the week, to make her a visit, I hoped to see Ada Swearingen to day, but she has a bad cold. taken on the Golf ground I think. To night we only had Mattie Badger to dinner with Mrs Shreve, Mr & Mrs Ballard, Shreve Bland Jr, and Mrs A.C. Badger. it has turned cold, and rain ceased at ten O.clock, Mr Stewart Bell called to night on Mrs Bland Balllard, Mr Ballard came home from Mr Austin Ballards dinner sick.

Monday, November 4, 1901
To day is beautiful sunny and cool, the rain of yesterday cooled off . the air Mr Ballard took cold, and feels very bad to day, but he went out. all well here now, Bland Jr better of his head, and Shreve better of his cold. My cough still holds on, but I am not sick, Ada Swearingen spent the afternoon with us, her cold is better. all kind of bad colds and coughs are very prevalent, The Misses Ballard called to see us all to day, they look well, and are keeping their Mother,s house, until they sell it. Ada brought me a very pretty bonnet as a present. She is very happy in her new home. Adele Ballard gone out visiting in the Carriage to say "good bye" to relations as she has taken the beautiful home of Mr John Dwight at Lake Forest for the winter to try change of climate for her childrens Malaria, they have fine schools there for her boys. and very choice society, and a good class of children, and very near the Beach, of Lake Michigan.

Mrs R.B. Boak & Miss Jeane arrived, at Mrs A.F. Badger,s to day in Chicago
Tuesday, November 9, 1901
It is quite cold, the sun is trying to shine, at eight O.clock Mrs A.F. Badger. sent her Carriage to the depot for Mrs Boak and her daughter Jeane, who will make them a visit all are well here in these two houses. My sister and Neice have houses next to each other, and have cut a door in the supper hall, which makes connected, without going out of the two big houses. My sister Virginia, who married Mr David Pratt Faulds owned One, and Mrs T.T. Shreve owned the other She died Mrs Faulds some years ago, and left one child who is now Mrs Octavius Fulton Badger. and she lives in her mother house, Mrs T.T. Shreve is a widow of many years, and occupies the other now she is alone with her servants, Emma a white maid, and Albert a coloured Coachman have been with her many years, true & faithful is daughter Mrs Bland Ballard (Adele Laurence Shreve) has lived with her Mother about 15 years. She now is going to Chicago, to find out, if the cold climate will be better for her boys, who have Malaria she has taken a beautiful furnished house owned by Mr John Dwight, he will rent it for the winter, and take a house in the city so as to let his daughter Florence, have a nice winter in the City

The Ballards (Bland) leave to night for Chicago for the winter 
Wednesday, November 6, 1901
Mrs A.C. Badger will leave with them for Chicago.
Another sunny day cool and beautiful all well here but Mr Bland Ballard, he has a real case of influenza, but some better to day, Dr Knueller sent him some Medicine to take, Mattie Belle Houston gives us a Luncheon to day. also has Miss Boak and Mrs Boak, and Adele Ballard. Mrs Shreve and Mrs A.C. Badger have sent their regrets. Mrs John Noyes called to see all of us. Says Miss Jeane Perry is in Chicago on Madison Avenue. taking singing and instrumental lessons, she is her Neice, and also related to Clarence Buckingham. her Father was Robert Perry. At seven O.clock we will go to the depot. after a fine dinner, Mr and Mrs Embry Swearingen came in to say "good bye" so did Mr & Mrs Houston Mr & Mrs A.F. Badger, Mrs Boak & Miss Jeane, David Belle & Adele Badger, all said good bye and we filled two Carriages, with lots of baggage all were reluctant to have me leave, we had four lower berths and two upper. I had One, Mr Ballard One, Mrs Bullard One, Shreve One, Bland Jr One upper. Katherine One upper she is governess, retired early. Spent a very good night

arrived in Chicago at eight O.clock, Elbert at depot for us. 
Thursday November 7, 1901
Mr A.C. Badger, Mr Bland Ballard and family.
It has been cloudy all day, looks like snow. but at 6 O.clock, the sky indicated a clearing up. and sure enough, to day is beautiful, warmer and a bright sun, Elbert Harvey had a Carrette waiting for us. We drove up to Mrs Harvey,s house. Fernwood Villa, 5810, Monroe Avenue. all delighted to see us, Ballards wild over their baby girl who they had left at Mrs Harvey,x with her nurse Katie. they were nine days at Louisville Mrs Harvey gave us a delicious breakfast, then the Ballards gathered up their baggage. and started for their new home, at Lake Forest. which the have rented all furnished, for the winter from Mr John Dwight, I remained at Mrs Harveys to Lunch, my daughter Ada Henry came over and took Luncheon with me. We had a happy time at three O.clock Ada Henry took me in her Carriage to her beautiful home, 3656 Grand Boulevard. Mr Badger came up to Mrs Henry,s with his satchel, and we will remain here a few days. My son Shreve telephoned me that he was delighted I had arrived safely. his family was crazy to see me, as I have been away over three months. most of the time at the Seaside. I found all my children and their families in fine health & prosperity they all look fat and rosy. and happy.

Mr & Mrs A.C. Badger visiting Mrs R.L. Hentry. for a few dats.
Friday, November 8, 1901
To day is faultless, warm and sunny. every one of our relation in fine health. we spent a delightful evening with all of Mrs R.L. Henry,s family, her four boys, and One little daughter. are very interesting, all good students and very far advanced. Mrs Henry is a wonderful executive Woman. four years she has been Paralyzed all one side. two years it very much injured her memory. but now she has improved so much, that she is quite herself mentally attends to all the demands of the home runs her entire Marketing, her Barn wants, assists her children with all their studies watches their musical lessons, runs her Seamstress, buy all her materials Takes entire control of her childrens movements and training, is down to her breakfast at half past six, reads her newspaper, and ready for breakfast before anyone comes down, attends Church twice a week, with her three boys, aged, 12. 14. & 18. Mr Henry dont attend Church. writes her letters, and keep up her Condolences and accomplishes a great deal in her science reading, and has no use of her left arm & very little of her limb, manages all her money, pays all bills-

Mr A.B. Meeker died at Utica New York.
Saturday, November 9, 1901
It was foggy early this morning, but at ten O. clock the sun came out, and the day has been beautiful, we spent the morning at home, boys gone to base Ball game they take part in it, so they are good players, after lunch, Mrs Henry ordered her Carriage and she, and I with William Wirt all went dawn to Mr Henrys Office, and Mrs Henry sent baby in to get his Father in the Club, he found him and we took him home I went to see my dentist, Dr Lazanne about pulling it, and he said come Monday, so we at through, Mr Badger got some dirt in his eye. and he wished for our Ada Badger to take it out. Huntington & Winston gone to night to dog show, Llewellyn gone to a party, all will be home at Twelve, I saw Alpheus Badger Jr. at dentist, he looked so handsome. Mrs Sheridan Badgers Mother Mrs Eldrige stopping at her daughters Mrs Frank Hoyne?. she lives in California, I telephones to my son Shreve, he said all were well. boys better of their colds, he very anxious to have us come to Kenilworth

Sunday, November 10, 1901
Today has been beautiful, warm and sunny so many people are out walking Mrs Henry. Llewellyn, Huntington, Winston, Oarville & A.C. Badger. all went to Scientist Church. found the Church, full of people I did not go, on account of my cough and who should come in to see me but my son Sheridan, and Stanwood, my grandsom, they both looked well, but had to leave on the One, O. clock train for Western Springs, the Mother of Sheridans wife, Mrs Eldridge from San, JosÃ© California is now at Sheridans house, at Western Springs for a few days, this lady first married Mr Ashton, then Mr Eldridge, Mr Brown dined with the Henry,s to day at noon, Mr & Mrs T.W. Harvey. called to see us to day. They look fine Little Frances Tuteur. spent afternoon with Camille, a neighbor ( a very pretty child of seven) Edgar Ewing a nephew of Judge Whig Ewing spent evening, and took Tea with Huntington Frances called up from Kenilworth to inquire after my cold, and Urge me to come out.

Monday, November 11, 1901
It is a rainy Morning, last night it rained we have had so much lovely sunny weather that we now miss it, I have an engagement at the Dentist, so has little Camille. Mrs Harvey expects this week to go to Denver to visit her daughter Belle Mason, and her two Grandchildren, little Belle Sheridan and baby Elvira. all are well I wrote last night to Mrs Shreve, Mrs Chas Harvey has come to Mrs Henry,s to spend the morning. and take lunch with us, it has rained all day. and now is colder, Llewellyn went this afternoon to several receptions, and to night to a party. I wrote a note of sympathy to Mrs A.B. Meeker and family. Llewellyn Henry is having his mother arrange the house for a party of sixty next Friday night, so to day clean curtains was put up all over the house, and every thing put in order for his University Club, he entertained it last I sent Frances a box of Candy. I bought in Louisville, I gave Mrs Henry a box of marsh-mellos, Paul Harvey gone on a tour of buisiness for his Father, they sell large Plants for reducing Gas.

Mrs A.C. Badger had two wisdom teeth, pulled out, they loose. 
Tuesday, November 12, 1901
At noon the sun came out warm. a beautiful day. Last night it rained, the the sun this morning is trying to shine, but many heavy clouds are passing so we may still have rain.  To day I have an engagement at the dentist Dr Lazarre. I expect to go, to morrow to Kenilworth, my home, I have enjoyed my visit here, with my daughter Ada, very much, she has improved so much the last three months, in general health. and she looks so handsome. and natural, and is so cheerful, and resigned, says her affliction of Paralysis, has been the greatest source of pleasure, and happiness, that she ever had, and she would not give up her experience, and knowledge of God, and his goodness to her and her family, if she had to choose, she would say, give me my past four years affliction, nothing on Earth could give more comfort. it has made all her family so tender, and considerate, of her, even the four year old boy, will run up to her, to lean on his head or arm, everyone is so thoughtful, Mrs T.W. Harvey & Elbert, dined here at Mrs Henry,s I went to Dr Lazarre, and he pulled out my two Wisdom teeth- they were very loose. Ada took me in her Carriage

Arrived at Kenilworth at five Mr & Mrs A.C. Badger. after being away for three months East.
Wednesday, November 13, 1901
Again a glorious sunny day, all well, my cough just the same. otherwise I am well. today at four O. clock, Mr Badger and I will go out to Kenilworth, for the Winter. Mrs Bland Ballard and family, like Lake Forest very much, they have such a beautiful home, all furnished, Bland. jr. has his old cold still, but is well. Elbert dined with them on Sunday. and went to church, in Lake Forest. Dr Mc Phearson, came on from Princeton to open the second Presbyterian Church rebuilt since it was destroyed by fire except the walls. there was a large crowd on Sunday morning. I read this morning until noon, took lunch and Ada ordered her large Carriage, and took me to the North Western depot to meet Mr AC Badger.  Camille, William Wirt, and Marie went with us, I said good bye, and Mr Badger soon came, and he started for Kenilworth. Frances had the Carriage at depot for us. and she and Nana and the dog Lassie were waiting for us, at the house, Edwin Shreve, Mrs Cowles & Mrs Rearden, were all waiting to receive us, house looks fine

Edwin & Shreve Badger, Donkey & Cart come to morrow. Mr Shreve Badger gone to Green Bay, to night. 
Thursday, November 14, 1901
Today is beautiful sunny and cool. all feel well, both the boys and myself still hold on to our coughs. Frances spent the day down town. I staid at home, played with Shreve the three children, Nan, Edwin and Shreve, been at home several days as the school is closed, One child of Mr Miller,s has scarlet diptheria but they don't think it will spread. To night my son, Shreve, left at seven O.clock to go to Green Bay. on business
Miss Mollen, here sewing for Frances, Today Mattie Sheridan arrived from New York. and stopped at the Auditorium, sent a letter to Mr A.C. Badger, saying she wanted some money, as she had been sick, and could not write for the magazines, as she had been doing. she wants to go to Europe. Frances has nice girls, Katherine, and Sylvia, and a washerwoman, and a man for Furnace and garden. Adele Ballard, wanted us, all to dine with her to night, but we had to decline She is settled at Lake Forest.

Llewellyn Henry had a large Club party to night. 
Frriday, November 15, 1901
Donkey came this morning from Glencoe. This has been a beautiful sunny day, all well except coughs. Soon after breakfast the Donkey that Shreve bought for his boys, from Mrs Shortall, Prairie Avenue. Grandchildren of Mr John G, Shortall. came safely from Glencoe, with its little wagon, the children were wild with delight and Frances was more delighted than the children, she rode the children all over Kenilworth, and had five little boys and girls, that she took also, she, and the children, spent all their day outside with the Donkey, and she had Mr Struggles all day fixing his stall. the two dogs Lassie and Don, had to be kept in the house away from the Donkey. they are collie,s. I have signed many certificates to night on the Bright Diamond Mine in Colorado,  To night is the Club Party of Llewellyn Henry,s about 60 people young Ladies and Gentlemen, they will have a good time, and nice supper. I was urged to be present, but I did not have my trunk with me, so could not stay, and it was too far to return. Mrs Rearden is better in health, and their Mother Mrs Cowles is very well.

Frances spent today at Mr Cowles
Saturday, November 16, 1901
Llewellyn Henry had a party Again we have a beautiful day, all well, coughs better, after breakfast Mrs Rearden had the coloured man hitch up the Donkey. they call him Gary, Nana, Edwin and Shreve, all got in the wagon, and had a fine time Frances went into Chicago and spent the day at Mr Alfred Cowles, they will change their Governess The men came to fix our gas, as it was leaking, and they To night at nine O.clock, my daughter Ada Henry. Let her son Llewellyn have his Club of seventy young Ladies, and Gentlemen, have a party at her house on Grand Boulevard 3656. They had, fine supper and a band of music, and all enjoyed the dance. Mrs T.W. Harvey. Sister of Mrs Henry went to the party as Chaperone, to assist Mrs Henry, and as it was a cold night, she staid, all night

Shreve returned from Green Bay to day
Sunday, November 17, 1901 Snow
Another sunny bright day, all well, coughs are better, the children were up this morning bright and lively, to go in the yard to see the Donkey. he gave one of his cries to call the children out, he wanted his lunch of sugar and water, after breakfast, Frances went out, and had William harness him to the wagon, and she took all the children in the neighborhood and gave them rides, at ten O.clock Mr Shreve Badger returned from Wisconsin, well and very happy to see the children, so pleased with the Donkey. Mr A.C. Badger took the eleven, O.clock to Chicago, and went to our daughters house, Mrs Robb-L, Henry,s to dinner, found them all well. they had just returned from Church. Frances returned from her ride, and walk, with the Donkey all tired with bad headache, to night Shreve, and Frances, went to our little Episcopal Church, they have a boy choir, Mrs Dr Adams, has left their home, and gone to the City, for her daughter to make her debut.

Snowed last night. Children at school, again. 
Monday, November 18, 1901
Today is clear, snow on the ground about two inches, weather mild to day the three children went to school. the school has been closed for ten days on account of Mr Miller,s child having diphtheria, To day the new dog house for Don, came made by Mr Miller, and to morrow he will fix a house for the Donkey, he had to stay out all night in the snow.  Mrs Rearden is all used up with stiffness and sore throat, taken in the drive she took with the Donkey.The snow has all melted now the man is putting up a barn for the little cart, and a man to take care of all, so it will be a costly plaything, but they are all very happy over it. they are very fond of Pets. Mrs Cowles and her daughters are particularly fond of the Country and their grandchildren the same (Mrs Cowles Grandchildren I mean)

Tuesday, November 19, 1901
Miss Mollen gone to Lake Forest to Sew for Mrs Ballard
Today is a beautiful, and sunny. all are well again, Yesterday Mrs Rearden had a severe sore throat, so she sent for the Dr. blank, he left her medicine, but she is much better this afternoon. There is in Chicago a great deal of throat trouble, and Grip, so the papers say. After breakfst, Frances had Jim harness up the Donkey, she wents some errands then went to the school for the children, they had a good ride, then she took all the neighbor children, then put up for Luncheon, at two O.clock, Frances went to Evanston, and took little Shreve with her. The workmen to day I think will finish the Barn for the Donkey and the shedd for the cart, Miss Mollen went this morning to Lake Forest, to sew for Mrs Bland for a week then she will return To night the dancing class, of young married people, meet at the Hall of Mrs Babcock, for pleasure & instruction I received to day an invitation from Mrs Addision Ballard & Mrs William, Mr Derby Jr. to a Reception November 30th My sister Mrs Shreve, has been sick in Louisville, her home, with cold.

Anniversary of Golden Wedding, just one year to night since it was celebrated
Wednesday, November 20, 1901
Again we have a glorious sunny warm day, all well my cough much better. children all at school. Little Shreve gone to Mrs Ware,s Cottage, to Luncheon, Nan Rearden and her Aunt Frances Badger, are going to Photographer to get a picture of Nan, To day is our Wedding Anniversary. One year since our fiftieth, celebration which we had at my daughters house. We had about fifty in number. Only relatives, we had it in the City, because our house in Kenilworth was too far out of the City. Yesterday frost and Fog. caused a great deal of accidents and some deaths, particularly to our Elevated roads. in a Cottage near us, are two sweet little girls, Julia and Mary Mallory. they are from Frankfort, Kentucky. they are very fond of our boys. and come over, and drive in our Donkey Cart with the boys. To night Mr Shreve Badger and Francis had a fine dinner in honor of our Anniversary, it is just one year since the golden wedding.

Shreve goes to night to Rinelander Wisconsin on buisiness
Thursday, November 21, 1901
To day is again sunny & beautiful, all well, my cough much better, I staid at home all day, as, Mrs Ed Mason, sent me word she would call, she will only stay a few days and then return to Denver, to her family she is my granddaughter, Belle Harvey. Frances Badger has gone to CHicago with SHreve, and Ned, for the afternoon, Nana is going to take the Donkey cart, and take some of her little friends to drive, to day my son Shreve goes to wisconsin on buisiness, I think it is Rinelander. I wrote my regrets to many Receptions Mrs Rockwell King & Miss- Mrs Joseph Bowen & Mrs W. M. Derby. jr. & Mrs Gen  Thomasson, Mrs Bland Ballard telephoned me last night from Lake Forest, that she wanted Mr Badger and I, to come and spend some days with her, they were all well there A letter from Ada Swearingen, of Louisville says all are well in her family, but my sister Mrs Shreve had been sick with severe cold. but now better. I think Mrs Shreve is visiting her daughter, Mrs Houston for a few days. They dont want her go back to her house so soon

Mrs T.W. Harvey, & Belle Mason, gone to Denver
Friday, November 22, 1901
To day has been very rainy, and cloudy. but not cold. the children have gone to school in the rain, little baby Shreve went also in the rain to Kindergarten Frances spent the day in Chicago First at the Dentist, then visiting. came home late. she took children out in the Cart Nana gone to have her picture taken Miss Edith Beason, is coming from Iowa , to spend some days with her Cousins Mis Beason is Mrs Cowles, sister, her name is Agusta Mrs Eldred, who is the mother of Mrs Gertrude Badger, is new at Mrs Hoyne,s and will remain there until after Thanksgiving, then go to Baltimore to visit her other daughter, Mrs

Mrs Geo. M.  Pullman,s invitation
Saturday, November 23, 1901
To day has been cloudy with light rain all well here, my cough much better, Frances, and Edwin and Nan, been out all day. I wrote to Mattie Belle Houston, received invitation from Mrs Geo. M. Pullman, and Mrs M. C. Sanger & Miss Grace Sanger. also invitation from Mrs Lavier Otis & Miiss Otis. had a nice letter from Mrs Henry my daughter and from A.C. Badger,s Granddaughter Adele Louise, and my Granddaughter too Frances, and my husband. A.C. Badger both went last night to a Hall, where they had a New England dinner, all dressed ni Costume, of the Puritan days, Frances wore a Costume of an English Mother, and she represented it well. Mr Reed took John Alden,s costume, after dinner, Mr McAfee auctioned off, all the eating that was left, at good prices, Mrs Adam,s bought the roast pig for five dollar,s  and gave it to the Rugby school. They all had lots of fun. and closed with a Spelling Match, which the grown people all took part.

Shreve came back from Wisconsin to day. Stanwood dined with us. 
Sunday, November 24, 1901
It has been raining all day, this morning at at ten O. clock. my son Shreve arrived home at Ten O. clock, loaded down with bande,s a large Hamper, filled with Veinison, a whole deer.) a large bundle of candy, and a gift for each one of us, mine was a China mug. Baby Shreve a lantern, each one something, after Shreve opened the venison box, he divided it in large peices, and gave some to Mr McAfee, and other friends, a peice for Mrs Henry, and for Alfred COwles, after eleven O. clock, our Grandson Stanwood Badger came and took with us. Lunch, and dinner, at three O. clock, my son Shreve, Frances, Stanwood, and A.C. Badger, all went to Lake Forest. to see the Ballards. found all well but Katie the nurse she is sick, Ballards are delighted with Lake Forest. Mr Harvey & Elbert there to stay all night. Stanwood came back to supper. left at. 8. for Western Springs

Paul Harvey is in New York
Monday, November 25, 1901
Today is cloudy and light rain, Mr Shreve Badgers cold very bad, but a little better than yesterday. A little dog followed Edwin home from school but it turned out to be Mrs Insull,s dog who was past so Nancy took him home, they live in Kenilworth, have rented Mrs Adam,s house. 
I wish my book was large enough to write some of the remarkable things that our new President Roosevelt, has said, and done since he become President he is a man of great force, and power and I think will please the people his wife is also a fine attractive woman of good sense & judgement They have fie children, and a grown daughter, who made her debut this winter Mils Alice Roosevelt. young, and pretty, who will christen the

Tuesday, November 26, 1901
Today has been cloudy, and damp. all well but Mr Shreve Badger he still has his bad cold, quite hoarse, Frances has been in Chicago all day came home late with Shreve they had to hurry and dress, as they were going to a dinner out and Reception given to Rev Mr Moore, at Mrs blank house he is the Episcopalian Minister of Kenilworth. I wrote my regrets to Mrs Phelps Hoyt, and to Mrs Geo Pullman, Mrs Re,elle, Roloson, and Mrs Xavier Utes. I had a long delightful letter, Ada Swearingen of Louisville and the picture, and letter from her Father, the large Church, and Parsonage, are the home of Ada,s Aunt Carrie Angell of Norway, (East) She has been Minister of that church for many years, all love her, she has had many calls elsewhere, but her large Congregation, love to hear her preach in her own pulpit. Ada is very happy in her married life of four months.

Wednesday, November 27, 1901
This morning is beautiful and sunny, and not very cold, all here are well, Some are very busy about their Thanksgiving dinner, I have made no engagement though as my cough was so much better I would not go out, and perhaps bring it back, the manicure lady was here this morning to dress Frances hands, Mils Mollen is here making a dress for Frances, there was a Dancing party to night at Babevik Hall, but as Shreve had such a bad cold, they gave it up. Frances, Nan and baby Shreve returned from Chicago late this afternoon, Shreve Jr. bought a Gun. Geo. M. Pullman Jr. is critically at Mateo California, his twin Brother Sanger, is at his bedside the Twins married Sisters Belle Badger of Louisville has Rheumatism in her limbs. Typhoid fever left Belle not strong, but she is very large and flesh. a handsome girl of fourteen, she has a sister, much younger and slender, but very strong, and bright is very much like her Mother. Very mature and brilliant

Thanksgiving day, at Kenilworth, 
Thursday, November 28, 1901
This is a beautiful sunny day, not very cold, all well but Mr Shreve Badger he still has a cold in his chest. he ordered out the Donkey and Cart and took all the children, for a drive it did not help his cold, we had Luncheon, then Shreve went out in the garden, and ran with the children and played unclear that gave him more cold, and made him cough. Mr A.U. Badger went into Chicago and took lunch with Mrs Henry his daughter, found all well. returned to our 6 O.clock dinner  Mrs Henry wanted him to stay to dinner but he had promised us he would return Mrs Bland Bullard telephoned from Lake Forest that she wantd, Mr Badger and myself & Shreve & Frances to come to dinner at Six O.clock, but we had to decline, much to our regret. We had a delicious dinner with a great variety of good things in the night Shreve had a chill, at three O.clock Frances put hot unclear on him, and he got warm.

Geo M. Pullman Jr dead.
Friday, November 29, 1901
To day is good, and sunny, but at four it clouded up, and looks like snow. Shreve,s cold was worse this morning so he did not go to his Office, and we put on a Mustard plaster on his chest, as he had pain, in his chest, which relieved him, Mr A.U. Badger went in to his office and unclear Dispatches, from San Mateo California say that Geo M. Pullman Jr. was a serious case of Pneumonia, his twin Brother danger is with him, and their wives, the twin Brother married Sisters, Later dispatch says Pullman is dying, the last dispatch says Pullman is dead, his wife refuses to let his Mother, have the body unless Mrs Pullman will recognize her, Mrs Pullman, opposed the Marriage, he was divorced from his first wife

Mr Sheridan Badger gone to Colorado
Saturday, November 30, 1901
This has been a glorious day, My son Shreve, has been threatened with Pneumonia, so he had to stay home two days, he had a relapse he took this cold ten days ago in Reinelander, got better, but had this relapse, he won't go out until Monday. Frances, and Mils Ms blank cars came to me today, saying Mrs Remard Walker will be at Hospital, I don't know her trouble she unclear, Mils Ida Drew, letters from my Ada Swearingen says she is well and happy. Today Mr Badger went to Oak Park to see his Sister Mrs Hilton who is sick with unclear Paralysis, she was so glad to see him, she lives with her daughter Mrs Henry Booth. Mr Sheridan, S Badger gone in the private bar of Mr Coles and Mr Haufman, to New Orleans first then to Denver to see some mines,

Sunday, December 1, 1901
A beautiful sunny day, until Six in the evening, when we had a good rain, but it cleared of in the night, all well here Mr Shreve Badger went back to business this morning, his cold better, but not gone. he has been at home for several days and been a very content man, none of us went to Church, Mr Badger and stayed at home and unpacked, two trunks, then we all went into the Parlous and talked, and played on the Piano, Church Music,

Ida Drew Walker very ill, 
Monday, December 2, 1901
A cloudy chilly morning, all well Mr Shreve Badger, went back to his business this morning, very early, when we came down to breakfast at seven, Shreve was gone, he had his breakfast. I am afraid the damp cold morning will be bad for him as he still has cold in his chest, but he is so regular, and faithful, to buisness that he seldom lets anything interfere, by his close attention he has built up a large buisness, he is truly a self made man, is most generous to his family but indulges himself very little, and only goes out at night with his wife, he is a real domestic man, he does a great deal for many, but he is not appreciated enough. he certainly deserves much praise and thanks, he is devoted to his two boys, the youngest Shreve Jr. is wonderfully like his Father, in many ways, Edwin is like is Mother in everything.

big snow storm at Kenilworth Mrs Gen Strong died.
Thursday, December 3, 1901
This morning was very dark. It commenced snowing at ten, and we have about two inches of Snow the storm was so severe at noon that I sent Katherine after him, Mr Shreve Badger went to Chicago to arrange for the Club party she will entertain this Thursday they number about blank and are called the Neighbor Club.  A man from the City came out and tuned two Piano,s. Nan Rearden has been sick two days at home with cold,  unclear two little boys here, are out with their sleds, they like the snow, it is hard to get them to come in, I see by the papers the death of Mrs Mary B Ogden, widow of the late General William, S Strong, and Mother of Mrs C. Pemberton Wurts, 441. Elm, Street she has mother daughter, 
I wrote to Mrs Ballard, also to Mr & Mrs Moses Wentworth, I sent regrets to party

Wednesday, December 4, 1901
It has been snowing all day, and is still snowing, all of us well, Mr Shreve Badger is well again, This is a busy day with Frances as she expects to morrow her Neighbor Club, that number about fifty. The snow is about two inches deep and still snowing Nana Rearden is still at home not feeling very well; Mrs Rearden is also complaining, Mils Mollen is still home, making some things for Nana. I had a telephone from Mrs Harvey and she wants Mr Badger and I, to bring our trunks to her house, and make her a visit My daughter Mrs Henry, also wants me to visit her for sometime, and a letter from Mrs Bland Bullard at Lake Forest, wants us to come and make her a visit so I don't know yet where I will commence. to night Mrs Rearden was taken ill, and Shreve sent her Dr Slolpt, he thinks he will soon relieve her.

Mr Shreve, Badger, & Neighbor Club. Mete here to day at three O.clock. 
Thursday, December 5, 1901
Today has been good, in the afternoon the Sun shone brightly, all, well, Mr Rearden is all right, but weak, Mils Mollen went on the eight O.clock train to Lake Forest. to sew some for Mrs Blank Bullard, then she will return here, Today at three O.clock, the Club all came to our house they number fifty, and are very agreeable interesting people, and very musical, all the ladies brought their Crochet, or embroidery for Christmas there was one Gentleman from Chicago who sang finely, he was Mr Miller Mrs Root and Mrs Taylor, played several Duets, Mrs Cosgrove sang well, and her daughter played for her, Mils blank sang. at five all were invited into the dining room, to a beautiful artistic table, flowers in the center, several small lamps, plenty of handsome silver, and Yellow ribbons, and pretty candies in forms. everything passed off delightfully. to night, Mr Shreve Badger and wife, gone to unclear, flowers, to a sick lady, and candy to Mr Loyd children

Friday, December 6, 1901
This has been a fine day, sun shining snow still on the ground and covering all the roofs and sheds and fences. all well, I have been busy fixing my closets, after lunch, Frances went to Chicago, to take dinner with her Cousin Alfred Cowles. and Shreve would go too, then after their dinner they all would go to the Theatre, Mr Cowles has a new Governess for his four boys, he is a widowers, I received to night an invitation from Mrs Henry Martyn Curtis and Mils Curtis for Dec fourteenth. 1502, Indiana Avenue. Mils Mollen came back from Lake Forest where she has been sewing for Mrs Bullard, she reports the baby not well to day from indigestion, all others well.

Saturday, December 7, 1901
Again a beautiful sunny day with the snow everywhere. Not very cold. at ten O.clock Edwin, Shreve Jr. and Nana, all went to dancing school, came home to Luncheon, then Frances took the three children went to Shreve,s Office, and he joined them and they all went to the unclear to the Free food show. and they had a great time saw the two boys on the Camel, two horses dive in a large bank of water, about fifty feet was this

Davids engagement.
Sunday, December 8, 1901
Snow is beginning to melt, but day not very cold, all here well. None of us went out to day Mr AC Badger and Frances. fixed all the red china sell I gave to Ada and will be sent to her in Louisville also three trunks, and a Crate of pictures, I looked over my Albums with many Photo,s I gave Shreve Badger Jr. a large red velvet Album full of Photo, which pleased him very much, I received a letter from any nephew, David Badger of Louisville anniversary his engagement to Mils Jeane Bouk of Chicago, who has been attentive for two years, it is also reported that Mrs Boaks oldest daughter is engaged. The engagement of Mils Caroline Fisher. is announced to Mr Arthur Danforth Reyle of New York Sister of Mrs Madison B Hemedy of Chicago and daughter of the Pate

Monday, December 9, 1901
To day has been cloudy, and looks like rain, we still have snow on the ground. all are well, Frances has gone into Chicago to do her Christmas shopping she returned home home late. Mils Mollen is still here, sewing for Frances. Frances says she did all she wanted for Christmas little Shreve Badger, spent all his day with me, me here cutting out pictures. he was very good. I am trying to make my plans to go in City, and visit Mrs Henry and Mrs Harvey. for a few days, I had a letter from little Adele Badger of Louisville, she writes that all are well, and are busy with their Christmas, she is a bright child of eleven years, and very mature of her years, she loves to write, and keeps all the families posed on what is going on. She is quite a wonder at school, with all her studies,

Mrs Gen Strong died
Tuesday, December 10, 1901
This has been a changeable day slight full of snow, then sunshine and cloudy, children gone to school I did not go out neither  Mrs Cowles or Mrs Rearden, Frances went to Chicago early, as she had made an engagement with her Cousin Mr Cowles to go with him and assist him to get presents for his children, and for his Mother in law,s large family in Manchester, they finished all using the morning Mr Shreve Badger did not feel well to night, he is not over his severe cold
I received a note of thanks from Mrs Pemberton Wurts, for letter of sympathy, on the death of her Mother Mrs Gen Strong.

Mr George W Swearingen very ill
Wednesday, December 11, 1901
This has been a beautiful day. Summry, no wind but snow on the ground. after breakfast, Mrs Rearden, and Frances, Edwin & Shreve, went into the City to have their hair cut. returned at eight, quite late. Mr Badger was on the same train Shreve came later, Frances tired out, all the others bright Mils Mollen will stay in town to morrow, Katie, Mrs Bullards nurse has a bad eye, and she has gone I looked over my jewelry to night and will give some of it away. I had a lovely letter from Ada Swearingen, she says that her George and Lalla, have had a great deal of pleasure, buying gifts for their relations, Father Swearingen had a severe sinking spell on Monday, and they thought he was gone, but he has rallied again, but it cast a gloom on them all, and took their heart out of Christmas, Gertrude Badger is still in town, her Mother will not leave before the twentieth

Thursday, December 12, 1901
This dark, and looks like rain, or snow the snow on the ground is all melting, we are all very well, to day Francis this morning had two men finish Ada Swearingen boxes of pictures and trunks and they will be sent to Louisville to morrow. I unpacked an old trunk of dolls. and found some that are very good to give to these children, Frances, Mrs Rearden, and Mrs Cowles all have their rooms all well cleaned and scrubbed for Mrs Redding who is expected this week from France.

Mr Robt L Hamlin dead
Friday, December 13, 1901
It rained last night, and has been snowing all day and turned quite cold, all well here, we all stayed home to day, I am writing to David Badger of Louisville I received an invitation from Mrs C.B. Puswell and Mrs Dudley Winston for Jan 1st, 1902 Mr Robert Hamlin, died
he is to be buried from the Kinsie Apartments, 150 Lincoln Park Boulevard Saturday
To day Nana Rearden had her 13th Birthday, she received many gifts to night her Aunt Frances badger gave her a fine dinner, with her large Cake full of Candles

Saturday, December 14, 1901
Snowing very fast and quite cold, a letter came from Mils Edith Benson who is Cousin of Frances, saying she would come in and spend some days with them, and a dispatch from New York came saying that Mrs Redding and daughter were in New York, and would remain there a few days, and arrive in Chicago about the twentieth, Mr Redding will come for Christmas dinner. Frances went in town to do some Christmas shopping

Mr Badger is better to day. 
Sunday, December 15, 1901
It is very cold, snow on the ground, and very difficult to warm the house, all of us well but Mr Badger, he is better, no one went to Church, I wrote some, but all the others reading, Mrs Re

Mr Badger is better and gone down town, 
Monday, December 16, 1901
Today is warmer, the ice on the windows is melting, so we can see out. It has been bitter cold, Mr Badger went to his Office to day, but he is very weak, and said he would not stay long down town, 
Francis is very busy, arranging her house for her Sisters family who have arrived in New York. and will be here on the twentieth 
Mr Redding will not be able to come before Christmas Eve. as he has business in New York, so his stay will be very short but his wife Myra, and daughter Josephine will remain longer. Mils Mollen will finish her dress making this week. then she goes to Mrs Bullard at Lake Forest to finish some sewing, Mrs Bullard, Husband and family with two nurses, go to Louisville, Saturday for Christmas reunion, her brother Tom Shreve will come from New York to visit his Mother also, Mrs Houston and family live in their beautiful home in Louisville, so they will all be together, Mr Bullard,s two sisters live there

Today at two O.clock Mr A.U. Badgers & I will go to Mrs Harveys
Tuesday, December 17, 1901
Today has been cold, but sunny and clear. I packed my trunk, and after lunch, Frances ordered the Carriage and we said good bye to all at home and went to the Kenilworth depot. Took the train there for Chicago. Had a nice trip arrived at Northwestern depot, there we met Mr Badger, went to the Carriage, Mrs Henry, & William Wirt and Nurse Marie, Mrs Badger went here to his Office, and Frances and I went to Marshall Feilds Store, Frances went in to get some goods, then she will return to Kenilworth, I went with Mrs Henry and she left me at Mrs T.W. Harvey,s house where Mr Badger will join me and we will spend a week. Mils Nena Lunt is at Mrs Harveys, making her a visit for ten days, Mrs Harvey,s dog Maisee has nine Puppies, one week old. Elbert and Paul Harvey look so handsome they went last night to Mils Shumways party, my son Sheridan Badger, arrived to day from Arizona, well, had a nice letter from Ada Swearingen, says her mouth is sore again from cold. Father Swearengen ill.

Mr George, W, Swearingen died at five O.clock to day in Louisiana
Wednesday, December 18, 1901
Again very cold, but sunny. all of us well. Frances telephoned me, to inquire after my health. We received a dispatch from Louisville saying that Mr George Swearingen died this morning at five O.clock. he is Father in law of Ada Badger he has been ill several months. Mils Nina Lunt has been out most of the day, she is taking a course at the University. Mrs T.W. Harvey went to a Reception at Mrs Albion Smalls. and to night Paul has gone to Mrs Small,s to a dance at nine O.clock, my son Sheridan gone to Muiquette.

My son Sheridan gone to Murquette.
Thursday, December 19, 1901
Cold but sunny, all well here at Fernwood Villa, 5810 Monroe Avenue the home of my daughter, Mrs T.W. Harvey. I wrote letters of condolence to Mr Swearingen his mother and my daughter Ada. I have not had any letters yet, telling me about his Fathers, death. all the rest well. after Luncheon, Mrs Harvey and Mils Nena Lunt went to a Reception at Prof Waite,s house,

Adele Louise Badger came home from boarding school Notre Dame Indiana
Friday, December 20, 1901
Very cold but sunny, all of us well, all morning Mrs Harvey and I did some sewing, for Christmas, at eleven O.clock, Mrs Harvey went down town to do some business And did not return until late. She took a severe cold, My Granddaughter Adele Louise Badger came from boarding school to day, all her family went to the train to meet her, I wanted to go very much, but cough kept me at home.

Elbert and Paul left at eight to night for Louisville for Christmas
Saturday, December 21, 1901
Another beautiful day sunny and cold sleighings and skating fine all of us well. been busy helping Belle yet her boys ready to go to Louisville Kentucky Bertha Botsford Harvey, had a long talk with Paul about property, through the telephone
I telephoned Mrs Gen Drew, she says her daughter Ida Drew Walker is a little better, she has a nervous desease, and it is seven weeks, that Mrs Drew has not seen her, as talking disturbs her. She was married in September. She is a very sick woman, her family are in great distress over her illness,

Mrs Ralph Isham engaged to Mils Otis
Sunday, December 22, 1901
This has been a glorious winter day snow on the ground, but sunny and not so cold, all well but Mrs Harvey she has bad cold. Mr & Mrs Henry called and spent the afternoon, Mr Ralph Isham is to be married to Mils Otis north side Mrs T.W. Harvey telephoned Mr Ralph Isham to day her congratulations he was much pleased, he has a little son, named Albert Keep Isham after his Grandfather, Albert Keep.

Monday, December 23, 1901
Today has been sunny and very mild, all well but Mrs Harvey. She has a bad cold, but is busy makeing white capes and hoods for her two Grandchildren in Denver, and I am helping her. Little Belle Sheridan Mason, and Elvira Mason, both Babies, Ada Smearingen sent a Christmas gift to Mrs Harvey. Ella Warger sent me a box of home made candy, and Cravat to Mr Badger, her Brother, Mrs Harvey has sent away many gifts, I wrote a letter to baby Shreve to day. Mr Badger wrote Ella a letter, also Sophie & Horace, Ada Swearingen sent gifts to all, they were all pretty and useful.

Christmas has arrived, with a rain, it is 1.O clock all day.  Gifts arriving Mr Harvey has stockings filled & gifts for us. 
Today again is fine mild & sunny snow still on the ground. all of us well but Mrs Harvey, she took cold while out shopping last week, she and I busy trying to finish some things to send to her Grandchildren in Denver, Mrs Ed Masons, children, My son Shreve telephoned me from his Office, that I better change my mind and come over there to Christmas dinner wishing me a very happy Christmas at five O.clock he went to the train to get Mr Joseph Redding his Brother in law, he married Myra Cowles of California, daughter of Judge Samuel Cowles.
