(deceased) his wife is living with my son Shreve, who married the other daughter, Frances Cowles, Mrs Redding and little daughter Josephine are going to Egypt, will be here a week to visit her Mother and Sisters, Mrs Rearden is one Sister, Mrs Redding the other and a brother, Mr Sam Cowles lives in California Mrs Harvey has two stockings full for me and Mr Badger, and other gifts.

Christmas morning
Wednesday, December 25, 1901
No snow to day, but mild and cloudy, yet, we must call it a good day, as it did not rain, We all arose with cheerful hearts, and a Merry Christmas for all, and with grateful hearts for our many blessings, and so thankful that all our families were well, and all having such good times, with their own families. The same as ourselves. of course we had One deep regret, that we all could not be together, in one house but we are so happy that all were in health. after our hearty greeting and giving of gifts, we all sat down to a lovely hot breakfast. We only numbered, Mr & Mrs Harvey, and Mr & Mrs AU Badger, Mrs Harvey,s cold better, Our first arrival was Stanwood and Adele Louise my Grandchildren, next came Mr & Mrs Charles Harvey and their three boys and little daughter Janet, grandchildren of Mr T.W. Harvey Sr then Mr Graysen & Mils Florence Graysen, and a Second Cousin, Mils E Harvey, we numbered 14 at table. had a grand dinner. after dinner Mr Sheridan Badger and wife came in, we had a lovely time, I played the Piano and all danced the old Virginia Reel. all the family played and sang by the Piano. So we all had a beautiful Christmas time, and many gifts

Putting away Christmas gifts, we all had many
Thursday, December 26, 1901
It is cloudy, but mild, all very well, but our Cook Annie, who is sick to day. I am busy this morning looking and putting away presents, a beautiful letter came from Elbert in Louisville saying he and Paul were having a grand time, we expect him home to night. Ada Swearingen of Louisville sent us all pictures of herself in bridal costume, and one in her black Satin Cloak and hat. all fine Mrs Henry telephoned herself to me inquiring after my cough. At Mrs Shreve,s house in Louisville she had a Christmas tree, very beautiful, Mrs Shreve gave two dinner,s to the Harvey young men, they were much entertained by friends, they are so gay down South, and now the College boys have Vacation, they are entertained with parties, and Luncheons, Theatre parties and dinners, there is so much going on, the young men and girls are nearly worn out but it is pleasant, and fascinating

Elbert Harvey came to day from Louisville
Friday, December 27, 1901
A clear sunny day not very cold, all of us well, Elbert arrived from Louisville this morning, happy as a bird he had a glorious visit, parties and Lunches, and walks and visits made by the wholesale, Paul will not return before Sunday, he is too happy for words with all his very beautiful girls, Belle Sheridan Houston is a reigning Belle, and much admired no one can have any thing without Belle Houston, she made her debut in October, every one loves her, many parties have been given to her. Miss Mollen spent day with us, I wrote a letter of sympathy to Mrs Perry, Ne, Smith, on the death of her Son Dunlap Smith, and wrote to his widow he died of Pneumonia, Mrs Harvey telephoned Mrs Shreve Badger to come and take Luncheon, and bring her Sisters Mrs Redding, Mrs Rearden and Mother Mrs Cowles, on Tuesday. but Mrs Rearden is not well, and Mrs Cowles will remain, Mrs Harvey has invited, Mrs George Harvey, Mrs Turlington Harvey, Mrs Robert Harvey, Mrs L.L. Badger, Mrs Shreve Badger and Mrs Redding

Our year 1901 is about to leave us, it has brought us many pleasures, no sorrow.
Saturday, December 28, 1901
To day has been good and mild but no sun, all well here, Mrs Harveys cold better, we have both been busy making little dress, and 2 white Caps and Capes, and waists as a New Years gift for little Belle Sheridan Mason and her sister Elvira in Denver. I telephoned Shreve to day and he said to night, he was going to Green Bay, would return Tuesday Mr Redding, Mr Shreve Badger Mrs Redding and Mrs Henry all have accepted an invitation to Lunch with Mrs Harvey on Tuesday.This afternoon, Mr Badger went to Oak Park to see his sister Licinia and Neice Carrie Booth. found them in their usual health, Mrs Licinia Hilton is failing in health. very fast, Carrie was fixing up a treat for some children for New Years. I am invited to several entertainments on New Years day but I have sent our regrets. as my cold is not yet gone, it is the result of the Grip I had some years ago, each winter it returns.

Mr and Mrs Gilbert Cowan arrived in Chicago at 8, Oclock from Louisville
Sunday, December 29, 1901
To day is cloudy, and looks like snow. all of us well, Mr Harvey,s cold better, Elbert gone to church, Mr A.C. Badger has gone to Kenilworth to dine at my son,s Mr Shreve Badger. Mr & Mrs Gilbert Cowan were to arrive to day from Louisville, and stop a few days at the Annex. Auditorium, she is the Granddaughter of Mrs G.W. Swearingen. We had a lovely dinner to day. and a young man, by the name of Mr Griffis. came and took dinner with us, he is at the University in Chicago, but came from Marietta Ohio, where he went to College. his Mother lives in blank Wales. he will get his diploma, and be a Doctor, Mrs Harvey played the Piano, and Mr Griffis sang many pretty hymns he has a fine voice.  I had a long lovely letter from Ada C. Swearingen, she received many handsome gifts, the beautiful red dinner and breakfast set of China, red border I sent Ada as Bridal gift was made in France, especially for one. it is a very complete sett. with Pitchers, Comports fruit bowl. Large salad bowl. butter plates, fruit saucers, besides - the full sett of Platters, Plates & dishes

Miss Nina Lunt Jr came this afternoon to stay all night, to go with Elbert to Mrs Morton,s party.
Monday, December 30, 1901
A beautiful sunny mild day, all well Mrs Harvey,s cold better. Mrs RL. Henry wants me to come to her house to morrow, Mrs Bland Ballard sent Stanwood Badger Alpheus Badger & Adele Badger, cravats for the boys, and silver hand mirror for Adele, Mrs Henry telephoned me that I must come, and make her a visit with Mr Badger, and my trunk I wrote Ada Swearingen a long letter of thanks for her lovely Christmas gifts, Miss Nina Lunt came with her satchel and her party clothes, to stay here to night, Elbert and her, have gone to Govenor Mortons to his daughter,s debut, party. Miss Nina Lunt is the daughter of Judge Horace Lunt of Colorado, Springs, his Father was Mr Orrington Lunt. deceased, who lived in Evanston, and did a great deal to build up Evanston, his widow survives him and one daughter and Judge Lunt his son of Colorado Mrs Gilbert Cowan arrived Sunday morning, and she, and her Husband went right out to Kenilworth, to see us all. Mrs T.W. Harvey invited them to a Luncheon but they had many engagements and declined.

Mrs T.W. Harvey had Luncheon for ten, it was so deliciously cooked. 
Tuesday, December 31, 1901
The Bells are ringing in the New Year (Adieu). Again we have a beautiful sunny day, all of us well. We breakfasted, at nine, then Miss Nina Lunt, Mrs A.C. Badger, assisted the girl arrange the flowers, and silver, for the Luncheon, at eleven O.clock. Mrs Shreve Badger, and sister, Mrs Joseph Redding, Mrs Redding has been in Paris France for two years with her little Josephine who talks french well, they will remain two years more, the first of January Mrs Redding & Josephine go to Egypt. to spend the winter, they lost their other daughter Myra, she was ill in Paris sometime, but she craved to return to her old home in San Francisco and in a few weeks she died there of Diabetes. Mrs Redding, Mrs Shreve Badger, Mrs RL Henry Mrs Charles Harvey, Mrs George Harvey Mrs Dr Robert Harvey, Mrs Turlington Harvey, Mrs T.W. Harvey Mrs Sheridan Badger, Mrs A C Badger, all took lunch here at two O.clock, Our Luncheon was choice, and delicious, quail beautifully cooked, so was everything, the Ice Cream Merangue was fine, so was the Tomato Jelly Lettuce and Mayonaise, the Clam Soup with whipped cream, and the fruit salad. everything lovely  Mrs Dr Robert Harvey. had her baby Beatrice come for her, to see her Grandma Harvey.

I must say Good Bye. to 1901, it has brought us many joys and no sorrows.
